PREFACE
   The Columbus Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company
in 1994, is being kept current by regular supplementation by American Legal
Publishing as of 2006.
   During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and
indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company under the direction
of Peter King, city attorney and Betty Jean Beshear, purchasing coordinator.
   The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor
decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation
without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number
designates, in sequence, the numbers of the title, chapter, and section. Thus,
Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most
instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine
vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions.
Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion.
   In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying
the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative
history is complemented by a prior code cross-reference table, which sets out
the location of individual sections of the prior code, and an ordinance
disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all
ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification. A
subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code
provisions by individual section numbers.
   This supplement brings the code up to date through Ordinance 27-2024, passed
August 6, 2024.

Chapter 1.01
CODE ADOPTION
   
1.01.010   Adoption.
   
1.01.020   Title--Citation--Reference.
   
1.01.030   Reference applies to all amendments.
   
1.01.040   Title, chapter and section headings.
   
1.01.050   Reference to specific ordinances.
   
1.01.060   Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code.
   
1.01.070   Effect of code on past actions and obligations.
   
1.01.080   Constitutionality.
   
1.01.090   References to prior code.
1.01.010 Adoption.
   There is adopted the city of Columbus Municipal Code, as compiled, edited
and published by Book Publishing Company, Seattle, Washington. (Ord. 95-23 § 1,
1995)
1.01.020 Title--Citation--Reference.
   This code shall be known as the city of Columbus Municipal Code and it shall
be sufficient to refer to said code as the city of Columbus Municipal Code in
any prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding
at law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to,
amending, correcting or repealing all or any part or portion thereof as an
addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the city of Columbus
Municipal Code. References may be made to the titles, chapters, sections and
subsections of the city of Columbus Municipal Code and such references shall
apply to those titles, chapters, sections or subsections as they appear in the
code. (Ord. 95-23 § 2, 1995)
1.01.030 Reference applies to all amendments.
   Whenever a reference is made to this code as the city of Columbus Municipal
Code or to any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of the city of Columbus,
Indiana, codified herein, the reference shall apply to all amendments,
corrections and additions heretofore, now or hereafter made. (Ord. 95-23 § 3,
1995)
1.01.040 Title, chapter and section headings.
   Title, chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to
govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of
the provisions of any title, chapter or section hereof. (Ord. 95-23 § 4, 1995)
1.01.050 Reference to specific ordinances.
   The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters of record
which refer to, or are otherwise connected with ordinances which are therein
specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included within
the code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding
provisions contained within this code. (Ord. 95-23 § 5, 1995)
1.01.060 Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code.
   The last ordinance included in this code was Ordinance 94-08, passed
February 1, 1994. (Ord. 95-23 § 6, 1995)
1.01.070 Effect of code on past actions and obligations.
   The adoption of this code does not affect prosecutions for ordinance
violations committed prior to the effective date of this code, does not waive
any fee or penalty due and unpaid on the effective date of this code, and does
not affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit posted, filed or deposited
pursuant to the requirements of any ordinance. (Ord. 95-23 § 7, 1995)
 1.01.080 Constitutionality.
   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for
any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not
affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code. (Ord. 95-23 § 8,
1995)
1.01.090 References to prior code.
   References in city forms, documents and regulations to the chapters and
sections of the former city code shall be construed to apply to the
corresponding provisions contained within this code. (Ord. 95-23 § 9, 1995)

GENERAL PROVISIONS

1.04.150   Severability of code.

1.04.010 Title for citation.
   The ordinances embraced in the following titles, chapters and sections shall
constitute and be designated as "The Municipal Code of the City of Columbus,
Indiana," and may be so cited. Such code may also be cited as the "Columbus
City Code" or "this code." (Prior code § 1-1)
1.04.020 Code application.
   This code shall refer only to the omission or commission of acts within the
territorial limits of the city of Columbus and to that territory outside this
city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any
constitutional provision, law or otherwise lawful contract.  (Prior code § 1-4)
1.04.030 Effective date of code--Repeal of general ordinances in conflict--
Savings clause.
   A.   All of the provisions of this code shall be in full force and effect
from the date of passage to I.C. 36-4-6-14, and the filing of two copies of
this code in the office of the Clerk, and all ordinances of a general and
permanent nature in force at that time which include the subject matter of the
chapters denominated herein, are repealed from and after said date.
   B.   Such repeal shall not affect any offense or act committed or done or
any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or
occurring before said effective date; nor shall it affect any ordinance
accepting gifts and dedications of real estate; nor any ordinance or resolution
promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by the city or authorizing the
issuance of bonds of the city; or other evidence of the city's indebtedness, or
any contract or obligation assumed by the city; nor shall said repeal affect
the administration's ordinances or resolutions of this code; nor shall it
affect transfer and appropriation ordinances; nor shall it affect ordinances
concerning annexation or dis-annexation of territories to or from the city, or
any ordinances changing or concerning names of streets, or opening and closing
streets, or ordinances commonly known as zoning map amendments; nor shall it
affect any right, easement or franchise, conferred by any person or
corporation; nor shall it affect any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending on
said date, except that the proceeding thereof shall conform as far as possible
to the provisions of this code. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 1-2)
1.04.040 Definitions.
   In the construction of this code and of all ordinances, the following rules
shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the
manifest intent of the common council:
   "City" means the city of Columbus, Indiana or the area within the
territorial limits of the city of Columbus, Indiana and such territory outside
of the city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any
constitutional or statutory provisions. The word "city" shall be construed as
if the words "of Columbus, Bartholomew County, Indiana," followed it.
   "Clerk" means the clerk of the city, a second-class city.
   "Code" means local government code of the city, which is designated as the
Columbus Municipal Code.
   "Common council" means the city legislative body made up of seven elected
councilmen.
   "Computation of time" means the time within which an act is to be done and
shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last. If the
last day is a Sunday or a holiday, it shall be excluded.
   “Controller” means the controller is the fiscal officer of the city, a
second-class city.
   "Council" means the common council of the city.
   "County" or "this county" means the county of Bartholomew, state of Indiana.
   "Et seq." is the Latin phrase meaning "and the following."
   "Gender" means words used in the masculine shall include feminine and
neuter.
   "I.C." or "Indiana Code" refers to state law found in the Indiana Code.
   "Joint authority" means all words giving a joint authority to three or more
persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority
of such persons or officers.
   "May" is permissive.
   "Mayor" means the mayor of the city.
   "Month" means a calendar month.
   "Must" and "shall" are each mandatory.
   "Number" means words used in the singular include the plural and the plural
includes the singular number.
   "Oath" includes an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which, by law,
an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words
"swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed."
   "Owner" applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety
of the whole or a part of such building or land.
   "Person" means any corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization
or any other group acting as a unit as well as a natural person.
   "Personal property" includes every kind of property except real property.
   "Preceding" and "following" means next before and next after, respectively.
   "Property" includes real and personal property.
   "Public place" means any street or highway, sidewalk, park, cemetery,
schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto and any lake or stream.
   "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   Reasonable Time. In all cases where any provision shall require any act to
be done in a "reasonable time" or "reasonable notice" to be given to any
person, such "reasonable time" or "notice" shall be deemed to mean such time
only as may be necessary in the prompt execution of such duty, or compliance
with such notice.
   "Shall." The word "shall" is mandatory.
   "Sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curb line and the
adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians.
   "Signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write.
   "State" and the words "the state" and "this state" mean the state of
Indiana.
   "State law references" mean the Indiana Code, I.C., and any subsequent
amendments.
   "Street" includes all streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts,
squares, boulevards, viaducts or other public ways in the city which have been
or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use.
   "Substantial property interest" means any right in real property that may be
affected in a substantial way by actions authorized by planning and development
laws of the state of Indiana, including a fee interest, a life estate, a future
interest, a present possessory interest or an equitable interest of a contract
purchaser.
   "Tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of such
building or land, either alone or with others.
   "Time" includes words used in the past or present tense and includes the
future as well as the past and present.
   "Written" or "in writing" mean any representation of words, letters or
figures whether by printing or otherwise.
   "Year" means a calendar year. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 1-3)
1.04.050 Interpretation of language.
   All words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and
approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others
as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be
construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning.
(Added during 1994 codification)
1.04.060 Grammatical interpretation.
   The following grammatical rules shall apply in the ordinances of the city
unless it is apparent from the context that a different construction is
intended:
   A.   Gender. Each gender includes the masculine, feminine and neuter
genders.
   B.   Singular and Plural. The singular number includes the plural and the
plural includes the singular.
   C.   Tenses. Words used in the present tense include the past and the future
tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable. (Added during 1994
codification)
1.04.070 Acts by agents.
   When an act is required by an ordinance, the same being such that it may be
done as well by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts performed by an authorized agent. (Added
during 1994 codification)
1.04.080 Prohibited acts include causing and permitting.
   Whenever in the ordinances of the city any act or omission is made unlawful,
it shall include causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering, or
concealing the fact of such act or omission. (Added during 1994 codification)
1.04.090 Computation of time.
   Except when otherwise provided, the time within which an act is required to
be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last
day, unless the last day is Sunday or a holiday, in which case it shall also be
excluded. (Added during 1994 codification)
1.04.100 Construction.
   The provisions of the ordinances of the city, and all proceedings under them
are to be construed with a view to effect their objects and to promote justice.
(Added during 1994 codification)
1.04.110 Repeal shall not revive ordinances.
   The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of an
ordinance or revive any ordinances which have been repealed thereby. (Prior
code § 1-6)
1.04.120 Effective date of ordinance.
   Unless otherwise expressly provided, an ordinance shall take effect when
passed according to Indiana Code 36-4-6-14. (Prior code § 1-7)
1.04.130 Copies on file.
   Two copies of the Columbus Municipal Code shall be kept on file in the
office of the clerk. It is the express duty of the clerk, or someone authorized
by the clerk, to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances
which indicate the intention of the Common Council to make the same a part of
the code when the same shall have been printed or reprinted in page form, and
to extract from such code all provisions which may be from time to time
repealed by the common council. These copies of such code shall be available to
all persons desiring to examine the same and shall be considered the official
code of the city of Columbus, Indiana. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 1-11
(c))
1.04.140 Amendments, additions and deletions.
   A.   Any and all additions or amendments to such code, when passed in such
form as to indicate the intention of the common council to make the same a part
thereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such code, so that reference to
the Columbus Municipal Code shall be understood and intended to include such
additions and amendments.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or amend
by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such code, or to insert or
delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such code in any
manner whatsoever which will cause the code, any ordinance or the law of the
city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating
this section shall be punished as provided in Section
1.12.010. (Prior code § 1-11 (b), (d))
1.04.150 Severability of code.
   If any title, chapter, section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of
this code is for any reason declared to be unconstitutional or invalid, such
decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code.
(Prior code § 1-8)
1.04.160 City seal.
   The city clerk shall be the custodian of the city's seal and affix it to
such documents and instruments as required. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code §
1-10)
Chapter 1.08
FORM OF GOVERNMENT
   
1.08.010   Organization of city government.
   
1.08.020   Class of city.
1.08.010 Organization of city government.
   The government of the city shall consist of four branches, those being:
   A.   Executive branch;
   B.   Legislative branch;
   C.   Fiscal branch; and
   D.   Statutory boards and commissions. (Prior code § 2-01)
1.08.020 Class of city.
   The City of Columbus shall be a second class city beginning January 1, 2024
pursuant to I.C. 36-4-l et seq. (Ord. 2022-18, 2022)
Chapter 1.12
GENERAL PENALTY
   
1.12.010   General penalties.
1.12.010 General penalties.
   A.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this code shall be guilty
of an ordinance violation.
   B.   Each day a violation of this code is committed or permitted to continue
shall constitute a separate offense.
   C.   Except in cases where a different punishment is prescribed by statute
or a specific section of this code, any person convicted of an ordinance
violation shall be punished by a fine not to exceed the maximum penalty allowed
under I.C. 36-1-3-8(10), or applicable subsequent statutory provision, as the
same may be amended from time to time.
   D.   The city may bring a civil action to enjoin any person from:
   1.   Violating any ordinance regulation or prohibiting a condition or use of
property: or
   2.   Engaging in conduct without a license if an ordinance requires a
license to engage in the conduct.
   E.   The court may suspend all or any part of a penalty imposed for an
ordinance violation and may require a condition of such suspension that the
defendant shall perform uncompensated work that benefits the community.
   F.   The city may recover all court costs, reasonable attorney fees, and
other expenses or costs associated with enforcement of the Columbus Municipal
Code. (Ord. 3-2024 § 1, 2024; Prior code § 1-9)

Chapter 2.02
COMMON COUNCIL
   
2.02.010   Authority generally.
   
2.02.020   Meetings--Regular.
   
2.02.030   Meetings--Special.
   
2.02.040   Presiding officer--Duties.
   
2.02.050   Application of Robert's Rules of Order.
   
2.02.060   Quorum.
   
2.02.070   Addressing council.
   
2.02.080   Vote--Decision.
   
2.02.090   Appointing citizens' committees.
   
2.02.100   Reading and passage of ordinances and other matters.
   
2.02.110   Amending the code.
2.02.010 Authority generally.
   The legislative branch of the city is the common council. The council shall
have the exclusive authority to adopt ordinances and appropriate tax moneys
received by the city, and to perform other necessary and desirable legislative
functions. (Prior code § 2-8)
2.02.020 Meetings--Regular.
   A.   Regular meetings of the Common Council shall be held at least once each
month at 6:00 p.m. pursuant to public notice.
   B.   At the hour affixed, the clerk shall call the roll, noting those
present and those absent. (Amended during 1994 codification; prior code § 2-9)
(Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Ord. 47-2019, 2019; Ord. 08-7, § 1, 2008)
2.02.030 Meetings--Special.
   A.   Special meetings of the common council may be held upon call made by
the mayor or presiding officer or by any four members of the common council. In
every case of a call for a special meeting, it shall be the duty of the person
authorizing the special meeting to duly notify the city clerk of such meeting,
and it is the duty of that officer to cause notice of such meeting to be
immediately served upon each member, either in person or by notice left at his
or her place of residence.
   B.   At special meetings of the common council only such ordinances or
resolutions shall be considered or acted upon or such communications received
as are specifically stated in the call for such special meeting. (Ord. 33-2023,
2023; Prior code § 2-10)
2.02.040 Presiding officer--Duties.
   A.   At the first meeting of the Common Council of each succeeding January,
the Common Council shall choose from its members a president and vice
president. (I.C. 36-4-6-8) and meetings shall be conducted pursuant to I.C. 36-
4-6-10 through 36-4-6-17, and in accordance with the rules and regulations
presently in force, which may be amended from time to time by proper ordinance.
The term of appointment as president and vice president of the common council
shall expire on the date of the first meeting of each succeeding January.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the presiding officer to sign all ordinances,
orders or resolutions passed by the common council before they are presented to
the mayor.
   C.   The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum at all common
council meetings. (Amended during 1994 codification; prior code § 2-11 (b) —
(e)) (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Ord. 47-2019, 2019)
2.02.050 Application of Robert's Rules of Order.
   "Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised" shall be authority on all questions
of parliamentary law and procedure not specifically covered by this chapter.
(Prior code § 2-14)
2.02.060 Quorum.
   A quorum of the common council shall consist of a majority of all members
elected, but no ordinance, order or resolution shall be passed which shall not
receive the votes of the majority of all members constituting the common
council. (Prior code § 2-15)
2.02.070 Addressing council.
   No one not a member shall be permitted to address the common council except
by permission of the presiding officer or by a majority vote of the council;
provided, that any officer of the city or his authorized deputy may, when
called upon by the presiding officer, make a report or give desired
information. (Prior code § 2-16)
2.02.080 Vote--Decision.
   The presiding officer shall decide whether any question is carried by an
affirmative or negative vote; but if he is in doubt of the yeas and nays or a
division is called for, the council shall decide. (Prior code § 2-17)
2.02.090 Appointing citizens' committees.
   The presiding officer may appoint citizens' committees for any special
purpose, either on his own motion or on motion of the majority of the council.
(Prior code § 2-18)
2.02.100 Reading and passage of ordinances and other matters.
   A.   All ordinances shall contain a title which briefly describes its
content and subject matter. All ordinances shall be read two times before they
may be put to a vote upon passage, unless these rules shall be suspended, and
such readings shall be by title only unless otherwise required by proper vote
of the council. No ordinance shall be passed upon the same day as it is
introduced except by unanimous consent, and then only in case there are present
and voting at least two-thirds of all the members elect of the common council.
   B.   No ordinance or other matter may be introduced unless it shall have
been first transmitted to the presiding officer of the common council at least
eleven days in advance and to each member of the common council at least seven
days in advance of such introduction, unless the common council shall vote to
take up consideration of such ordinance or other matter by suspending the rules
or otherwise dispose of such ordinance.
   C.   All ordinances shall be read by the title when introduced and may
thereafter be referred to a committee by the presiding officer or held over
until a future meeting, unless the common council shall vote to take up
consideration of such ordinance by suspending the rules or otherwise dispose of
such ordinance.
   D.   All votes upon the passage of ordinances, resolutions and upon motions
to suspend the rules shall be by yeas and nays, unless a roll call vote is
requested.
   E.   All resolutions presented for any action by the council shall contain a
title which briefly describes its content and subject matter and shall be read
by the clerk by title only unless by proper motion and vote by the council, it
determines that the resolution should be read in its entirety, and immediately
thereafter it shall be acted upon by the council.
   F.   The agenda, along with all ordinances, resolutions and other written
matters to be considered by the common council, shall be posted at the entrance
of its chambers at least one day prior to each open meeting. (Prior code § 2-
19)
2.02.110 Amending the code.
   All ordinances which are of a general and permanent nature, and which would
amend the Columbus Municipal Code, shall be in the following form:
   Ord. No.                     
   (Include the last two digits of the calendar year preceded by a dash and the
chronological number of the ordinance: Ex. 1-86)
   (Short Title)
   An Ordinance of the Common Council of the City of Columbus, Indiana,

Chapter 2.04
COUNCILMANIC DISTRICTS
   
2.04.010   Division into six Councilmanic districts.
   
2.04.020   Common Council members; voting for candidates.
2.04.010 Division into six Councilmanic districts.
   The City of Columbus is hereby divided into six councilmanic districts,
which shall be known as the First District, Second District, Third District,
Fourth District, Fifth District, and Sixth District. These districts are
identified as follows and consist of the precincts and areas listed:
   A.   First District: Precincts 0100, 0300, 2000, 2200, 2300, and 2400.
   B.   Second District: Precincts 0200, 0225, 0250, 3100, 4450, and 5800.
   C.   Third District: Precincts 0400, 1500, 1600, 1700, 1900, and 2100.
   D.   Fourth District: Precincts 1000, 1100, 1200, 1300, 1400, 2900, 3550,
and 3500 prt.
   E.   Fifth District: Precincts 0500, 0600, 0700, 0800, 2500, 2600, 3300,
3350, 3400 prt, and 4250.
   F.   Sixth District: Precincts 0900, 1800, 2700, 2800, 2850, and 3850.
   G.   Seventh District: At-large.
   H.   Eighth District: At-large.
   I.   Ninth District: At-large.
The map attached to Ord. 44-2022 depicts the above districts and is
incorporated herein.
(Ord. 44-2022, 2022; Ord. 39-2022, 2022; Ord. 39-2012, 2012; prior code § 2-1)
2.04.020 Common Council members; voting for candidates.
   The Common Council is composed of six members elected from each of the
districts and three at-large members. Each voter of the city may vote for three
candidates for at-large membership and one candidate from the district in which
the voter resides. The three at-large candidates receiving the most votes from
the whole city and the district candidates receiving the most votes from their
respective districts are elected to the Common Council.
(Ord. 44-2022, 2022; Ord. 39-2022, 2022; Ord. 39-2012, 2012: Ord. 94-30, 1994:
Ord. 92-64, 1992)
Chapter 2.06
CITY OFFICERS AND DEPARTMENTS GENERALLY
   
2.06.010   Individual surety bonds--Blanket bonds.
   
2.06.020   Membership in organizations--Authorized.
   
2.06.030   Membership in organizations--Expenses to attend meetings.
2.06.010 Individual surety bonds--Blanket bonds.
   A.   Pursuant to Indiana Code, 5-4-1-18, and 36-10-3-16, the minimum blanket
bond is authorized, established and required in the minimum amount of fifteen
thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for the following positions:
   1.   Mayor;
   2.   Clerk;
   3.   Controller;
   4.   Employees of the Depai1ment of Finance;
   5.   Public Works and Utilities Clerks;
   6.   Community Development employees;
   7.   Parks and Recreation Director;
   8.   Associate Director to Parks and Recreation;
   9.   Secretary of Fire Pension Board;
   10.   Secretary of the Police Pension Board;
   11.   Any employee of any city department who handles money in the
performance of their duties.
   B.   Pursuant to Indiana Code 5-4-1-18, and individual surety bond is
established and required for the city Controller and Barrett Law custodians, in
an amount equal to thirty thousand dollars for each one million dollars of the
receipts of the office during the last fiscal year for the purchase of said
bonds but not to exceed in any event, the sum of three hundred thousand
dollars. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Ord. 91-12 § 1, 1991: prior code § 2-52)
2.06.020 Membership in organizations--Authorized.
   The common council, is authorized to budget and appropriate funds from the
general fund or from other funds to provide membership for the city, and its
elected and appointed officials and members of the municipalities' boards,
council, departments or agencies in local, regional, state and national
associations of a civic, educational or governmental nature, which have as
their purpose the betterment and improvement of municipal operations. (Prior
code § 21-25)
2.06.030 Membership in organizations--Expenses to attend meetings.
   A.   The common council, is further authorized to budget and appropriate
funds to pay the expenses of duly authorized representtives of the city, to
attend the meetings and functions of organizations to which the municipality
belongs.
   B.   The budgeting and appropriation of such funds by the common council
shall constitute full authority for membership in such associations as may be
therein contained. (Prior code §§ 21-26, 21-27)
Chapter 2.08
MAYOR
   
2.08.010   Duties.
   
2.08.020   Deputy mayor--Position abolished.
2.08.010 Duties.
   The mayor is the city executive and head of the executive branch. He shall
have and faithfully perform the duties and responsibilities contained in
Indiana Code 36-4-5-1 et seq., and any other applicable statutes. (Prior code §
2-11 (a))
2.08.020 Deputy mayor--Position abolished.
   The position of deputy mayor is abolished. (Ord. 96-6 § 1, 1996: Ord. 89-77
§ 1, 1989: prior code § 2-12)
Chapter 2.10
CITY CLERK
   
2.10.010   Created.
   
2.10.020   Election--Term.
   
2.10.030   Powers and duties.
   
2.10.040   Deputy clerk.
2.10.010 Created.
   The office of the city clerk in the city is established. (Ord. 33-2023,
2023; Prior code § 2-4 (a))
2.10.020 Election--Term.
   A.   The city clerk is elected by the voters pursuant to Indiana Code 3-10-
6 et seq.
   B.   The city clerk shall take office at twelve noon on the first day of
January following his or her election, and serve for four years and until a
successor is elected and qualified pursuant to Indiana Code 3-10-6. (Ord. 33-
2023, 2023; Prior code § 2-4 (e), (f))
2.10.030 Powers and duties.
   A.   The clerk shall be the clerk of the common council. It shall be his or
her duty, as such clerk of the common council, to make and keep accurate
minutes, and journal of the proceedings and to enter the yeas and nays on the
passage of every ordinance and resolution. Further, it is his or her duty to
provide each member of the common council with one copy of the minutes of the
preceding common council meeting at least seven days in advance of the next
regularly scheduled meeting, counsel may dispense with a full reading of same
and such minutes may be approved as written upon motion duly made, seconded and
adopted.
   B.   The clerk shall be the clerk of the board of public works and safety.
It shall be his or her duty, as such clerk of the board of public works and
safety, to make and keep accurate minutes, and journal of the proceedings and
to enter the yeas and nays on the passage of every matter coming before the
board of public works and safety.
   C.   The clerk shall be the clerk of council and shall perform the duties
prescribed by Indiana Code 36-4-6-9 and such other duties as the council may
direct. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 2-4 (b), (c) and (g))
2.10.040 Deputy clerk.
   The city clerk may appoint the number of deputies and employees authorized
by the city legislative body. The clerk's deputies and employees serve at the
clerk's pleasure pursuant to Indiana Code 36-4-11-4. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior
code § 2-4 (d))

shall be referred to as the controller. The controller shall be appointed by

(Ord. 33-2023, 2023)
2.11.030   Controller powers and duties.
   A.   The controller shall perform all duties as required by I.C. 36-4-1 0-
5 and other duties prescribed by the mayor.
   B.   The controller of the department shall establish an annual budget for
the city and is empowered to employ such appropriate staff as shall be
necessary to conduct its business, and other personnel deemed appropriate as
authorized by the common council, and the department shall be governed by such
administrative rules as may be established by the mayor and common council.
(Ord. 33-2023, 2023)

Chapter 2.14
ANIMAL CARE SERVICES
   
2.14.010   General Manager.
   
2.14.020   Duties, jurisdiction and powers.
   
2.14.030   Compensation.
   
2.14.040   Penalty for interference with animal care services personnel.
2.14.010 General Manager.
   The position of Animal Care Services General Manager shall be employed by
the City of Columbus, under the supervision of the Mayor or Mayor's designee
with the advice of the Animal Care Services Commission. The Animal Care
Services General Manager shall be authorized to employ staff and any other
persons as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter. (Ord.
48-2019, 2019; Ord. 32-2019 § 1, 2019; Ord. 7-2014 § 1, 2014; Ord. 13-2012 § 1,
2012; Ord. 08-17 § 1(part), 2008; Ord. 91-6, 1991; prior code § 4-6)
2.14.020 Duties, jurisdiction and powers.
   The Animal Care Services General Manager and staff shall be sworn to uphold,
carry out, and supervise the enforcement of this chapter within the city,
unless otherwise provided. The Animal Care Services General Manager and staff
shall be vested with all the powers ordinary and necessary under the law to
enforce the provisions of this chapter. These duties and powers shall
specifically include, but not be limited to the following:
   A.   To educate the public concerning humane ethics, consequences of pet
overpopulation and their responsibilities as pet owners;
   B.   To maintain the physical facility known as the Columbus Animal Care
Services Center which shall be operated in a humane manner in accordance with
the standards set forth in this chapter and established rules and regulations;
   C.   To make an annual report to the common council concerning the animal
care services program within the city;
   D.   To prepare and submit to the common council for approval an annual
budget of funds adequate to carry out the purposes of this chapter;
   E.   The power to apprehend and impound any animal that appears to be stray
or at large;
   F.   The power to apprehend and impound any animal that is on the owner's
property without being under the owner's personal physical restraint or posing
an immediate physical danger to the community. Such impoundment must be
preceded by written certification by a citizen witness, or by an officer of
Animal Care Services or by the police department. However, no animal shall be
apprehended and impounded if the owner is available and is restraining the
animal unless the animal is being confiscated pending an investigation;
   G.   The power to apprehend and impound any animal when the Animal Care
Services General Manager or staff have probable cause to believe that the
animal has been treated cruelly, inhumanely, neglected or used by the owner/
agent in a fighting contest;
   H.   The power to issue official warning or a notice of ordinance violation
for violations of this chapter;
   I.   The power to enter private real property in pursuit of an animal to
enforce this chapter. In performing their duties, the Animal Care Services
General Manager and staff shall be specifically prohibited from the following:
entering an inhabited or locked dwelling unit without the dwelling unit owner's
permission or without a warrant authorizing the entry except when apprehending
and impounding an animal pursuant to Subsection G. of this section, carrying
firearms or making arrests of human beings.
(Ord. 48-2019, 2019; Ord. 32-2019 § 1, 2019; Ord. 7-2014 § 1, 2014; Ord. 13-
2012 § 1, 2012; Ord. 08-17 § 1(part), 2008; Prior code § 4-7)
2.14.030 Compensation.
   The salaries and wages of the Animal Care Services General Manager and staff
shall be fixed by the mayor and approved by the common council. (Ord. 48-2019,
2019; Ord. 32-2019 § 1, 2019; Ord. 7-2014 § 1, 2014; Ord. 13-2012 § 1, 2012;
Ord. 08-17 § 1(part), 2008; Prior code § 4-9)
2.14.040 Penalty for interference with animal care services personnel.
   Whoever forcibly assaults, resists, opposes, obstructs, prevents, impedes,
or interferes with any Animal Care Services personnel while that person is
engaged in the execution of any duties required of the Animal Care Services
Department under this chapter, shall be subject to a fine of one hundred
dollars for the first offense, with the fines increasing by increments of one
hundred dollars for each subsequent offense within one year of the first
offense, but not more than one thousand dollars. (Ord. 48-2019, 2019; Ord. 32-
2019 § 1, 2019; Ord. 7-2014 § 1, 2014; Ord. 13-2012 § 1, 2012; Ord. 08-17 § 1
(part), 2008; Prior code § 4-8)

Chapter 2.18
DEPARTMENT OF CODE ENFORCEMENT
   
2.18.010   Department and office.
   
2.18.020   Chief code enforcement officer--Appointment--Term of office--
Removal.
   
2.18.030   Chief code enforcement officer--Duties.
2.18.010 Department and office.
   A.   There is established in the city the department of code enforcement.
   B.   There is established an office of code enforcement which shall include
the city board of zoning appeals organized under Indiana Code, 36-7. The office
of code enforcement shall be responsible for faithfully and diligently
enforcing any and all housing, building and zoning codes applicable to the
city. (Prior code §§ 2-49, 5-26)
2.18.020 Chief code enforcement officer--Appointment--Term of office--Removal.
   A.   The chief code enforcement officer shall be appointed by the mayor. His
appointment shall continue during good behavior and service and he shall not be
removed from office except for cause established after full opportunity has
been given him to be heard on specific charges.
   B.   The chief code enforcement officer shall be accountable and responsible
to the mayor. (Prior code § 5-27)
2.18.030 Chief code enforcement officer--Duties.
   The chief code enforcement officer is authorized and directed to enforce all
the provisions of the building code as adopted in this chapter. (Prior code §
5-28)
Chapter 2.20
POLICE DEPARTMENT
   
2.20.010   First-class patrolman.
   
2.20.020   Overtime compensation policy.
   
2.20.030   Police pension fund created.
   
2.20.040   Board of trustees created.
   
2.20.050   Retiring police officers and service revolvers.
   
2.20.060   Paid leave.
   
2.20.070   Vacation days.
   
2.20.080   Police reserve officers.
2.20.010 First-class patrolman.
   A.   There is now created the rank of first-class patrolman for the police
department. A "first-class patrolman" shall be defined as a policeman with
twenty years of active service as a regular permanent policeman for the city. A
patrolman upon acquiring twenty years of active service with the police
department shall automatically be promoted to the rank of first-class
patrolman. The sole criterion for this promotion shall be the acquisition of
twenty years of active service. This promotion shall not include any increase
in salary nor any change in job requirements, authority, responsibilities or
description.
   B.   A first-class patrolman must work a full year beyond his twenty years
active service with the police department before he is entitled to additional
pay.
   C.   This section in no way alters or vacates any rights a policeman may
have under the Indiana Code. (Prior code § 24-1)
2.20.020 Overtime compensation policy.
   That the overtime compensation policy for exempt and nonexempt employees of
the Columbus City police department shall be as follows:
   A.   Columbus police officers who hold "nonexempt" positions and, in the
course of their duties, are required to work beyond their regularly scheduled
hours of assignment, shall receive compensatory pay at the rate of one and one-
half the normal hourly rate for all hours worked above one hundred seventy-one
hours in the twenty-eight consecutive day work period which has been
established in compliance with the Fair Labor Standards Act.
   B.   The regularly scheduled hours of work assignment for all Columbus
police officers is recognized as a minimum of one hundred sixty hours in the
twenty-eight day work period. The extra hours worked between one hundred sixty
and one hundred seventy-one by nonexempt employees shall be compensated in pay
or compensatory time off at the rate of one times the hourly rate. Subject to
the approval of the chief, personnel may receive compensatory time off in lieu
of pay. Personnel may accumulate and save a maximum of sixty hours of
compensatory time. All hours accumulated in excess of sixty hours shall be
taken off by the end of the next consecutive work period.
   C.  All work hours shall be recorded on a daily work form which must be
signed by the officer, verified by an authorized supervisor, then submitted for
approval. Computation of all work hours shall be based on a twenty-eight day
work period.
   D.   Any employee may be required to work overtime. Prior supervisory
approval is required for all overtime worked.
   E.   Employees exempt from the application of the Fair Labor Standards Act,
as amended, by virtue of their job duties and responsibilities may be
compensated for extra time worked in the form of compensatory time off at the
rate of one hour of compensatory time off for each hour worked beyond one
hundred sixty hours within the applicable work period. No cash payment will be
made for unused compensatory hours at the time of the exempt employee's
termination. (Ord. 98-29 § 1, 1998: Ord. 94-08, 1994: prior code § 24-13)
2.20.030 Police pension fund created.
   There shall be and is created in the city a police pension fund. (Prior code
§ 24-6)
2.20.040 Board of trustees created.
   There shall be and is created and established in the city a board of
trustees of the police pension fund. (Prior code § 24-7)
2.20.050 Retiring police officers and service revolvers.
   A.   The chief of police of the police department is authorized to transfer
ownership of the handguns carried by members of said department to retiring
police officers with twenty years of service to said department.
   B.   The policy of the common council, shall be that only one handgun shall
be transferred to each qualified retiring officer. (Prior code § 24-8)
2.20.060 Paid leave.
   A paid leave package for the Columbus police department will now be
implemented under the following guidelines:
   A.   Eligibility. Based upon current police department policy (12/15/80), an
officer may become eligible for a sixty- day paid leave period upon the
satisfaction of each of the following conditions:
   1.   That the officer has served actively for at least nineteen years and
six months.
   2.   That the officer provides a letter of intent to retire from the
Columbus police department stating his intention to retire on or after his/her
twenty-year anniversary date, as established by the State of Indiana Public
Employees Retirement Fund Agency.
   3.   That the officer's letter of intent to retire is then received by the
chief of police.
   B.   Discretionary approval. The sixty-day paid leave period may be granted
at the sole discretion of the chief of police. The chief of police shall deny
an officer's request should the officer have failed to meet each of the
foregoing conditions of eligibility. The chief of police shall have sole
discretion of the scheduling and dispensing of this time.
   C.   Active time. The sixty-day paid separation/ transition period shall be
treated as active time, all of which is commensurate with the definition of
“active time” as defined by the State of Indiana Public Employees Retirement
Fund Agency. This time shall be in addition to any unused accrued vacation and/
or holiday time not already taken by the officer upon his/her date of
retirement
   D.   Revocation of intent to retire letter. In the event that the officer
withdraws his/her intent to retire after said paid leave period has commenced,
the paid leave days already exercised by the employee will be deducted from the
sixty- day total remaining upon his/her eventual retirement.
   E.   Severance pay. Eligible officers also entitled to receive severance pay
as set forth under Policy & Fire, Policy 14, Resignation, Discharge,
Retirement, Section 3.0, General Statement, Subsection (c) Retirement, will
still be afforded such pay. However, where an eligible officer receives paid
leave as authorized under this section, that same officer will have his
severance pay offset accordingly, so that no officer shall ever receive more
than sixty days of paid leave or severance pay combined.
(Ord. 06-33, 2006)
2.20.070 Vacation days.
   The Columbus Police Department vacation time shall be reflected as follows:
   A.   Employees who have completed at least one continuous year of full-time
employment, but less than five years:
   1.   Officers working twelve-hour shifts shall have ten (120 hours) workdays
off;
   2.   Officers working ten-hour shifts shall have ten (one hundred hours)
workdays off:
   3.   Officers working eight and a half-hour shifts shall have ten (eighty-
five hours) workdays off; and
   4.   Officers working eight-hour shifts shall have ten (eighty hours)
workdays off.
   B.   Employees who have completed at least live five continuous years of
full-time employment, but less than ten years;
   1.   Officers working twelve-hour shifts shall have fifteen(one hundred and
eighty hours) workdays off;
   2.   Officers working ten-hour shifts shall have fifteen (one hundred and
fifty hours) workdays off;
   3.   Officers working eight and a half-hour shifts shall have fifteen (one
hundred twenty-seven and a half hours) workdays off; and
   4.   Officers working eight-hour shifts shall have fifteen (one hundred
twenty hours) workdays off.
   C.   Employees who have completed at least ten continuous years of full-time
employment, but less than twenty years:
   1.   Officers working twelve-hour shifts shall have twenty (two hundred and
forty hours) workdays off;
   2.   Officers working ten-hour shifts shall have twenty (two hundred hours)
workdays off;
   3.   Officers working eight and a half-hour shifts shall have twenty (one
hundred and seventy hours) workdays off; and
   4.   Officers working eight-hour shifts shall have twenty (one hundred and
sixty hours) workdays off.
   D.   Employees who have completed at least twenty years of continuous full-
time employment:
   1.   Officers working twelve-hour shifts shall have twenty-five (three
hundred hours) workdays off;
   2.   Officers working ten-hour shifts shall have twenty-five (two hundred
and fifty hours) workdays off;
   3.   Officers working eight and a half-hour shifts shall have twenty-five
(two hundred twelve and a half hours) workdays off; and
   4.   Officers working eight-hour shifts shall have twenty-five (two hundred
hours) workdays off. (Ord. 37-2018, 2018)
2.20.080 Police reserve officers.
   The chief of police of the Columbus police department is authorized to
provide for any number of police reserve officers. Police reserve officers
shall be regulated by general order(s) of the Columbus police department, which
shall remain in compliance with state law.
(Ord. 23-2012 § 1, 2012)
Chapter 2.22
FIRE DEPARTMENT
   
2.22.010   Payment policies for training exercises.
   
2.22.020   Board of trustees and firefighter's pension fund established.
   
2.22.030   Overtime compensation.
   
2.22.040   Twenty-year firefighter longevity.
2.22.010 Payment policies for training exercises.
   The personnel policy of the city, is amended for purposes of insuring that
all sworn firefighters of the fire department participating in training
exercises sanctioned by the department be compensated by payment of straight
time, which is defined as the regular hourly rate of each individual of the
fire department, for each hour said sworn firefighters participate in said
training exercises sanctioned by the department. (Prior code § 8-44 (a))
2.22.020 Board of trustees and firefighter's pension fund established.
   A.   The city has established a firemen's pension fund and a board of
trustees of such fund as provided by applicable state law.
   B.   Section 3.20.190 addresses this topic further. (Prior code § 8-24)
2.22.030 Overtime compensation.
   A.   Any and all personnel practices and policies that are inconsistent with
the provisions and requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 are
repealed.
   B.   The city of Columbus adopts a workperiod of twenty-eight days,
commencing on January 2, 1998, and continuing in perpetuity thereafter unless
modified by ordinance of the common council of the city of Columbus, Indiana,
for the purpose of computing overtime compensation for qualified fire
personnel.
   C.   Qualified fire personnel are defined as all sworn public employees
playing an integral part in firefighting operations, receiving firefighting
training and holding a position with a rank at or below Battalion Chief and
working a 24 hour shift.
   D.   The base pay per workperiod of qualified fire personnel shall include
compensation for two-hundred and twenty-four hours. For actual time worked in
excess of two-hundred and twelve hours and up to and including two-hundred and
twenty-four hours, qualified fire personnel shall receive additional hourly
compensation at a rate of one-half of regular hourly wages. For actual time
worked in excess of two-hundred and twenty-four hours, qualified fire personnel
shall receive additional hourly compensation at a rate of one and one-half
times regular hourly wages. Such overtime compensation shall be in lieu of any
and all compensatory time.
   E.   The city, in order to increase its efficiency and cost effectiveness,
shall be granted full discretion in scheduling qualified fire personnel to
work, and in granting vacation and sick leave.
(Ord. 1-2015, 2015; Ord. 98-5, 1998; prior code § 8-39 (a)–(f))
2.22.040 Twenty-year firefighter longevity.
   A.   General Statement. This benefit shall apply to all firefighters who
have no officer rank, paramedic rank, nor any other specialty rank which
receives more than a firefighter's base salary, but who complete twenty years
of service with the rank of firefighter in the city.
   B.   Policy. A firefighter for the city receives a first class firefighter's
salary, as defined by Indiana Code 36-8-1-11, when completing twenty years of
service, receiving all longevity increases of twenty years or less, as provided
by the city, and earns upon his twentieth year an additional first class
longevity.
   This first-class longevity is based upon an additional amount as determined
annually by the city controller and approved by the board of public works and
safety which results in making the firefighter's retirement equal to the police
officer's retirement.
   The first class firefighter shall receive all other benefits as defined by
police and fire personnel ordinances and policies which apply. (Ord. 33-2023,
2023; Ord. 94-57, 1994)
Chapter 2.24
DEPARTMENT OF AVIATION
   
2.24.010   Established.
2.24.010 Established.
   There is established a department of aviation to be controlled and operated
by the board of aviation commissioners established pursuant to Indiana Code, 8-

Chapter 2.26
DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
   
2.26.010   Established.
   
2.26.020   Department head--Budget--Staff--Rules.
   
2.26.030   Community economic development fund established--Sources.
   
2.26.040   Limitation of powers.
2.26.010 Established.
   There is established a department of community development within the city,
for the planning, administering, coordinating and carrying out, directly or
indirectly, of community development and related activities for the city.
(Prior code § 2-45)
2.26.020 Department head--Budget--Staff--Rules.
   There is established a department of community development. The head of this
department shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of
the mayor. The department shall establish an annual budget and is empowered to
employ such appropriate staff as shall be necessary to conduct its business,
and other personnel deemed appropriate; and the department shall be governed by
such administrative rules as may be established by the mayor. (Prior code § 2-
46)
2.26.030 Community economic development fund established--Sources.
   The city establishes a community economic development fund, the moneys in
which shall not revert to the general fund of the city at the end of fiscal
years; and the department of community development may accept and place in such
fund moneys from appropriations of the common council and grants from the
federal government, from private donations and from any other source. (Prior
code § 2-47)
2.26.040 Limitation of powers.
   The department of community development shall not exercise any powers vested
exclusively in any other taxing district or separate municipal corporation.
(Prior code § 2-48)
Chapter 2.28
DEPARTMENT OF LAW
   2.28.010   Establishment, appointment and duties.
   2.28.020   City attorney and assistant city attorney.
   2.28.030   Appointment and compensation of assistant city attorneys.
2.28.010 Establishment, appointment and duties.
   A.   There is established a department of law.
   B.   The head of the department of law shall be referred to as the
corporation counsel. The corporate counsel shall be appointed by the mayor and
serve at the pleasure of the mayor (see I.C. 36-4-9-6(3).
   C.   The corporate counsel shall be admitted to the practice of law in
Indiana and be a resident of the county in which the city is located.
   D.   The corporate counsel shall faithfully perform the duties as described
in I.C. 36-4-9-12. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 2-22)
2.28.020 City attorney and assistant city attorney.
   A.   The corporation counsel's first deputy shall be called the city
attorney. The corporate counsel's second and subsequent deputies shall be
referred to as assistant city attorneys (see I.C. 36-4-9-11).
   B.   The corporate counsel may appoint the number of assistant city
attorneys and employees as authorized by the city legislative body. The city
attorney, assistant city attorneys and other employees of the department of law
shall serve at the pleasure of the corporation counsel. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023;
Prior code § 2-23)
2.28.030 Appointment and compensation of assistant city attorneys.
   The assistant city attorneys shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure
of the city attorney and the compensation shall be established by the annual
budget ordinance as passed by the common council. (Amended during 1/97
supplement; prior code § 2-24)
Chapter 2.30

   There is established a department of parks and recreation to be controlled
and operated by the parks and recreation board established pursuant to Indiana
Code, 19-7-4, now Indiana Code, 36-10-3. (Prior code § 19-5)
Chapter 2.32
DEPARTMENT OF PERSONNEL
   
2.32.010   Established.

   There is established a department of personnel which shall be responsible

Chapter 2.34
DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING
   
2.34.010   Established.
   
2.34.020   Planning director--Established--Responsibilities.
   
2.34.030   Planning director--Tenure and salary.
   
2.34.040   Plan commission.
   
2.34.050   Plan commission--Qualifications, terms and removal of members.
   
2.34.060   Professional organizations and conferences--Payment of fees.
2.34.010 Established.
   There is established a department of planning which shall include the city
plan commission, organized pursuant to applicable state law. The director of
the department shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the
plan commission. He shall be primarily accountable and responsible to the plan
commission of the city. (Prior code § 2-25)
2.34.020 Planning director--Established--Responsibilities.
   A.   The office of planning director of the city is established.
   B.   The planning department shall be responsible for the development,
execution and continuous updating of a comprehensive plan for the city, and
such other duties and responsibilities that may be assigned from time to time
by the plan commission. (Prior code § 2-29)
2.34.030 Planning director--Tenure and salary.
   The tenure and salary of the planning director shall be fixed and set by the
plan commission subject, however, to annual appropriation for such salary by
the common council. (Prior code § 2-30)
2.34.040 Plan commission.
   There is created and established an advisory plan commission to be known as
the city plan commission which shall have such duties and powers as established
by Indiana Code, 36-7-4-200 et seq., and such other responsibilities as may be
assigned to it from time to time by the common council. The commission shall
consist of eleven members to be appointed as follows:
   A.   One member by the common council from its membership;
   B.   One member to be appointed by the park board from its membership;
   C.   One member or designated representative appointed by the board of
public works and safety;
   D.   The city engineer or a qualified assistant appointed by the city
engineer;
   E.   Five citizen members, of whom no more than three may be of the same
political party, appointed by the mayor. Citizen members so appointed shall
reside within the corporate boundaries of the city;
   F.   Two citizen members, who may not be of the same political party, shall
be appointed by the commissioners of Bartholomew County, Indiana. Citizen
members so appointed shall reside outside the corporate limits of the city but
within the jurisdiction of the plan commission. (Prior code § 2-26)
2.34.050 Plan commission--Qualifications, terms and removal of members.
   A.   Each citizen member shall be appointed because of his knowledge and
experience in community affairs, his awareness of the social, economic,
agricultural and industrial problems of the area, and his interest in the
development and integration of the area. A citizen member may not hold other
elective or appointive office in municipal, county or state government.
   B.   The term of office of a member who is appointed from the membership of
the common council, the park board or the board of public works and safety
shall be coextensive with the member's term of office on that body, unless that
body appoints at its first regular meeting in any year, another to serve as its
representative.
   C.   The term of office for citizen members shall be four years. Each
member's term expires on the first Monday of January of the fourth year after
the year of the member's appointment. A member serves until his successor is
appointed and qualified. A member is eligible for reappointment.
   D.   If a vacancy occurs among the members of the plan commission, the
appointing authority shall appoint a member for the unexpired term of the
vacating member.
   E.   The appointing authority may remove a member from the plan commission
for cause. The appointing authority must mail notice of the removal, along with
written reasons for the removal, to the member at his residence address. A
member who is removed may, within thirty days after receiving notice of the
removal, appeal the removal to the circuit or superior court of Bartholomew
County. The court may, pending the outcome of the appeal, order the removal or
stay the removal of the member. (Prior code § 2-27)
2.34.060 Professional organizations and conferences--Payment of fees.
   If the plan commission determines that it is necessary or desirable for
members or employees to join a professional organization or to attend a
conference or interview dealing with planning or related problems, the
commission may pay the applicable membership fees and all actual expenses of
the members or employees, if that amount has been appropriated by the common
council. (Prior code § 2-28)
Chapter 2.36
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY CENTRAL DISPATCH
   
2.36.010   Established.
   
2.36.020   Department head.
   
2.36.030   Coordinator.
   
2.36.040   Supervisors.
   
2.36.050   Civilian dispatch employees and personnel policy.
   
2.36.060   Department budget required.
2.36.010 Established.
   The department of public safety central dispatch is established by the
common council of the city. (Prior code § 2-70)
2.36.020 Department head.
   The chief of the police department and the chief of the fire department
shall collectively be the department head for said department and shall
hereinafter be designated as "department head." (Prior code § 2-71)
2.36.030 Coordinator.
   The coordinator of the department shall be the combination officer of the
police department. The responsibilities of the coordinator shall be to assist
the department head of the department in carrying out all duties and functions
of the department. (Ord. 91-57 (part), 1991: prior code § 2-72)
2.36.040 Supervisors.
   The department shall have a supervisor who shall be the communication
officer of the police department. The supervisor shall be responsible for the
day to day supervisor and scheduling of all civilian dispatchers working for
the department. The supervisor shall report to the head of the department.
(Ord. 91-57 (part), 1991: prior code § 2-73)
2.36.050 Civilian dispatch employees and personnel policy.
   The department head shall be responsible for the hiring of all civilian
dispatch employees serving the department. All said civilian dispatch employees
of the department shall be governed by the personnel policy of the city, as
adopted and amended, and all applicable internal rules and regulations of the
department not inconsistent with the personnel policy of the city; provided,
however, that given the special operating needs of the department, the
department head shall have the authority to establish a work schedule which may
have the effect of compensating the department personnel for their lunch
periods. Policy 9.3 of the personnel policy for the civil city of Columbus,
Indiana, is amended, for this department only, to allow operation in a more
efficient manner. All other portions of the personnel policy for the civil city
of Columbus, Indiana, not amended or modified herein shall remain in full force
and effect. (Prior code § 2-75)
2.36.060 Department budget required.
   The department head shall present to the common council of the city, during
the normal yearly budgetary hearings, the budget of the department. The common
council may, from time to time, appropriate moneys from the general fund that
are necessary to properly execute and operate the department. (Prior code § 2-
74)

Chapter 2.40
UTILITY SERVICE BOARD
   
2.40.010   Established.
   
2.40.020   Composition.
   
2.40.030   Members--Appointment.
   
2.40.040   Members--Term of office.
   
2.40.050   Members--Compensation.
   
2.40.060   Officers and meetings.
   
2.40.070   Budget required.
2.40.010 Established.
   There is created and established a utility service board to operate and
manage the utilities owned by the city. (Prior code § 2-34)
2.40.020 Composition.
   The utility service board shall be composed of five members, not more than a
majority of whom shall be members of the same political party. (Prior code § 2-
35)
2.40.030 Members--Appointment.
   Three of the members of the utility service board shall be appointed by the
mayor and two of the members shall be appointed by a majority vote of the
common council. (Prior code § 2-36)
2.40.040 Members--Term of office.
   The term of office for the members of the utility service board shall be for
four years; provided, that initial appointments by the mayor and council shall
be made so as to permit alternating terms in future appointments. (Prior code §
2-37)
2.40.050 Members--Compensation.
   The members of the utility service board shall serve without salary but
shall be entitled to reimbursement for any expense paid out by them in
performing the duties of their office. (Prior code § 2-38)
2.40.060 Officers and meetings.
   The members of the utility service board are authorized to select a chairman
and any other officers deemed necessary to properly carry out the functions of
such board. Also, the members may adopt and prescribe rules to conduct their
meetings and business coming before them. (Prior code § 2-39)
2.40.070 Budget required.
   A.   The common council mandates that the utilities service board shall
submit to the common council, the annual budget of said utilities service board
in November of each year.
   B.   The common council establishes that the common council shall have the
authority to review, revise, delete and amend any and all provisions of the
annual budget submitted by the utilities service board. After completing the
review of the budget so submitted, the common council shall approve said budget
by resolution, as amended, revised or deleted, in December of each year.
   C.   This section shall become effective as of January 1, 1987. (Prior code
§ 2-39.1)
Chapter 2.42
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS GENERALLY
   
2.42.010   Statutory boards and commissions enumerated.
2.42.010 Statutory boards and commissions enumerated.

(1977 Fund), concerning the statutory pensions of city police.
   B.   There shall be a firefighters' pension board of trustees to perform
certain duties prescribed by Indiana Code 36-8-7 (1937 Fund) and Indiana Code
36-8-8 (1977 Fund), concerning the statutory pensions of city firefighters.
