Chapter 2.66
CITY HALL FACILITIES COMMITTEE
   
2.66.010   Established.
   
2.66.020   Membership.
   
2.66.030   Organization.
   
2.66.040   Duties and responsibilities.
2.66.010 Established.
   The city hall facilities committee is established. (Prior code § 2-54)
2.66.020 Membership.
   A.   The city hall facilities committee shall consist of six members as
follows:
   1.   Mayor or his or her designee;
   2.   Two members of the common council;
   3.   One citizen member appointed by the mayor;
   4.   One citizen member appointed by the common council;
   5.   The superintendent of building and grounds who will serve as an ex
officio member.
   B.   The two citizen members shall serve for four-year terms with the first
appointment to be one appointment for a four-year term and one appointment for
a two-year term. The elected members appointed shall serve until replaced.
   C.   All initial appointments to the city hall facilities committee shall be
made within fifteen days after the effective date of the ordinance codified in
this section. (Prior code § 2-55)
2.66.030 Organization.
   A.   The city hall facilities committee shall meet within fifteen days
following the appointment of all of its members for the purposes of organizing
and electing a chairman from among its members. Thereafter, the committee shall
meet during the month of January of each year. The chairman shall serve until a
successor shall have been selected.
   B.   The members of the committee shall serve without compensation. Such
members may, however, be reimbursed for approved out-of-pocket expenses
incurred in the performance of their duties. (Prior code § 2-56)
2.66.040 Duties and responsibilities.
   The city hall facilities committee shall:
   A.   Conduct an annual inspection of building and grounds during the month
of March;
   B.   Provide an annual report to mayor and council as to general condition
of building and grounds within thirty days after the annual inspection;
   C.   Make recommendations for the following year's capital improvement
budget for City Hall;
   D.   Develop a five-year plan for the replacement and/or modification of the
physical plant and grounds;
   E.   Review any requests for changes inside or outside the building,
covering, but limited to, such areas as: landscaping, site planning, exterior
buildings, present building architecture, interior walls or objects to be
placed thereon, appointments, additional or remodeling of furniture, carpet,
drapes, accessories and other related items;
   F.   Interview and make a recommendation to the board of public works and
safety for any architectural assistance needed relative to the building and
grounds, and review any architectural recommendations prior to board of public
works and safety action on such recommendations;
   G.   Analyze and make recommendation to the board of public works and safety
concerning changes necessary to comply with any local, state or federal
statutes, or laws relative to safety and health;
   H.   Perform such other duties and assume such other responsibilities as the
mayor and the common council may appropriately assign to it. (Prior code § 2-
57)
Chapter 2.68
CLAIMS REVIEW COMMITTEE
   
2.68.010   Established--Composition--Powers.
2.68.010 Established--Composition--Powers.
   A.   A committee is established to investigate, review and settle claims
brought against the city for amounts within the terms of the city's insurance
policy and the amounts of the deductible for such policy. The committee shall
act upon tort claims, claims for damages, contract damages and any other claims
for damage against the city or any of its agents or employees acting within the
scope of their employment, and, only on amounts up to fifty thousand dollars.
On claims more than fifty thousand dollars, the committee shall advise the
board of public works and safety, who shall act upon the recommendations of
said committee.
   B.   The committee shall be called the claims review committee. The
committee shall meet in whole, or in part, as necessary. It shall require
agreement from a majority of the committee before any loss claim settlement is
acted upon. Any settlement amount for any claim shall be presented to the board
of public works and safety in the form of a signed claim and purchase order.
Before final payment to a claimant will be made, a signed release, as approved
by the city attorney's office, must be signed by the claimant and a witness or
a notary public.
   C.   The committee shall consist of the following persons:
   1.   The fiscal officer of the city;
   2.   The city attorney;
   3.   The deputy mayor of administration;
   4.   The loss prevention coordinator;
   5.   The department head of the department against which the loss or claim
was initiated. (Ord. 92-36, 1992)
Chapter 2.70
COLUMBUS ETHNIC EXPO COMMITTEE
   
2.70.010   Established.
2.70.010 Established.
   A.   There is established an ethnic expo committee to be appointed by the
mayor for purposes of conducting a city-wide celebration of the ethnic
diversity of the city.
   B.   There is established a special nonreverting account in the department
of community development from which private contributions to sustain the
activities of the ethnic expo committee may be paid. (Ord. 92-44, 1992)
Chapter 2.72
INSURANCE REVIEW COMMITTEE
   
2.72.010   Established.
   
2.72.020   Membership--Appointments.
   
2.72.030   Membership--Terms.
   
2.72.040   Duties.
2.72.010 Established.
   There is established an insurance review committee to serve without
compensation, consisting of one member of the common council, one member from
and representing the police or fire department, one member from and
representing the utility service department, one member from and representing
the park and recreation department and five members from the private sector.
Additionally, the mayor (or his/her designee) and the city attorney (or his/her
designee) shall serve as ex-officio members of the committee without voting
rights and shall not be counted for purposes of determining the presence of a
quorum of members present to conduct business. (Ord. 4-2021 (part), 2021; Ord.
96-14 (part), 1996: prior code § 2-58)
2.72.020 Membership--Appointments.
   A.   The mayor shall appoint three of the members from the private sector
and shall appoint the representative members from the police or fire
department, the utility service department and the park and recreation
department.
   B.   The common council shall appoint its member of the committee and shall
also appoint two of the members from the private sector. Common council
appointments will be made by the current council. (Ord. 4-2021 (part), 2021;
Ord. 96-14 (part), 1996: prior code § 2-59)
2.72.030 Membership--Terms.
   Each member of the committee shall serve for a term of three years, with the
exception of the police or fire department representative, the common council
member, and the two members of the private sector appointed by the common
council, who shall serve for one year. The police or fire department
representative shall consist of a member of the police department in even
numbered years and shall consist of a member of the fire department in odd
numbered years. (Ord. 4-2021 (part), 2021; Ord. 96-14 (part), 1996: prior code
§ 2-60)
2.72.040 Duties.
   It shall be the duty of the insurance review committee to periodically
review all insurance obligations and/or coverages held by the city and make
recommendations concerning coverages to the appropriate boards and authorities
concerning modifications or updates in obligations and/or coverages, at all
times considering the cost effectiveness of such insurance obligations and/or
coverages. The insurance review committee shall further send such
recommendations to the board of public works and safety or appropriate board
who shall select the most appropriate insurance coverages available from said
recommendations or if said recommendations are not acceptable then refer the
matter back to the review committee for further study of the matter. (Ord. 4-
2021 (part), 2021; Ord. 96-14 (part), 1996: prior code § 2-61)
Chapter 2.76
CITY PROPERTY
   
2.76.010   Disposal of property.
2.76.010 Disposal of property.
   The city shall follow the provisions of Indiana Code, 36-1-11-1, et seq.
when disposing of property. (Prior code § 7-50)
Chapter 2.78
LOCAL DISASTER EMERGENCIES
   
2.78.010   Declaration of local disaster emergency--Authority.
   
2.78.020   Declaration of local disaster emergency--Effect.
   
2.78.030   Determination of need for declaration of local disaster emergency.
   
2.78.040   Coordination with county commissioners.
2.78.010 Declaration of local disaster emergency--Authority.
   The mayor is authorized to declare a local disaster emergency in accordance
with the terms of Section 10-4-1-23 of the Indiana Code. (Prior code § 5.1-1)
2.78.020 Declaration of local disaster emergency--Effect.
   Upon the declaration of a local disaster by the mayor, the mayor and the
board of public works and safety, shall exercise all powers and authority
granted to local political subdivision and to its principal executive officer
under the provisions of Title 10, Article 4, Chapter 1, of the Indiana Code.
(Prior code § 5.1-2)
2.78.030 Determination of need for declaration of local disaster emergency.
   In times of natural disaster or civil emergency, the mayor is authorized to
activate the city emergency operations command post. The chief of the city
police, the chief of the city fire department, the Bartholomew County health
officer, the Bartholomew County emergency services coordinator and the
Bartholomew County emergency preparedness coordinator, or their designated
representatives, shall assist the mayor in evaluating the need for the
declaration of a local disaster emergency. (Prior code § 5.1-3)
2.78.040 Coordination with county commissioners.
   All actions commenced pursuant to this chapter, shall be coordinated to the
greatest extent possible with the county of Bartholomew, Indiana, and the
chairman of the board of commissioners of Bartholomew County, Indiana, pursuant
to the Joint Bartholomew County-City of Columbus Emergency Operations Plan
developed pursuant to this chapter and Bartholomew County Ordinance 1985-4.
(Prior code § 5.1-4)
Chapter 2.80
PERSONNEL RULES AND REGULATIONS
   
2.80.010   Chapter applicability.
   
2.80.020   Personnel policies--Adopted by reference.
   
2.80.030   Adoption of Act and Amendments--Council to perform obligations.
   
2.80.040   City-owned vehicle regulations.
   
2.80.050   Deferred compensation plan.
   
2.80.060   Coverage elected.
   
2.80.070   Positions to be covered.
2.80.010 Chapter applicability.
   This chapter shall apply to employees of the city no matter in which
department of the city or under which city board the employee may be working.
(Prior code § 21-1)
2.80.020 Personnel policies--Adopted by reference.
   A.   The personnel policies updated by ordinance in 2022, which are on file
in the office of the city clerk, are incorporated by reference and are accepted
and approved by the common council. The personnel policies are open for public
inspection during regular business hours.
   B.   Said personnel policies shall be followed by all city departments and
employees except these specifically exempted therein.
   C.   Said personnel policies shall remain in full force and effect until
changed by amending ordinance of the common council.
   D.   All personnel policies and rules and regulations in conflict with the
personnel policies adopted herein are repealed. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code
§ 21-3)
2.80.030 Adoption of Act and Amendments--Council to perform obligations.
   For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of Title 11, Section 218 of
the Federal Social Security Acts and Amendments thereof, the agreement entered
into between the state with the approval of the governor and the Social
Security Administrator is made a part of this chapter and shall constitute an
integral part of the federal agreement between this political subdivision and
the state agency and shall become a part of the agreement or modification of
the agreement between the state and the Social Security Administrator. The
common council explicitly agrees that it wilfully perform the obligation of a
political subdivision under federal-state agreement. (Amended during 1994
codification; prior code § 21-17)
2.80.040 City-owned vehicle regulations.
   A.   Definitions.
   A "control employee" is an elected official and all department heads,
appointed by the mayor, responsible for city government functions.
   "City employee" means a full-time employee of the city, responsible for city
government functions.
   “Marked qualified non-personal use law enforcement vehicles” are:
   a.   Owned by the City of Columbus;
   b.   Readily apparent that it is a police vehicle through an insignia or
words on the exterior of the vehicle. However, a marking on a license plate is
not sufficient;
   c.   Operated by a Public Safety Officer who is always on call, required to
use the vehicle for commuting and who has arrest powers in the State of
Indiana: and
   d.   Prohibited from persona! use outside the state of Indiana.
   A "nonpersonal use vehicle" is any vehicle provided for use by an employee
for the conducting of city business only, for which that personal use.
including commuting, is prohibited, and which is kept on city premises.
   “Public safety and special use vehicle” is any of the following:
   a.   Clearly marked police or lire vehicles of full-time police officers or
firefighters who are on call at all limes which cannot be used for personal
use. other than commuting, inside the officer's arrest or firefighter's
response jurisdiction;
   b.   Unmarked law enforcement vehicles where the full-time law enforcement
officer has the power of the arrest and regularly carries a firearm and the use
is incidental to law enforcement functions as authorized herein;
   c.   Ambulances and hearses;
   d.   Bucket trucks, dump trucks, garbage trucks and flatbed trucks;
   e.   Utility repair trucks that the employees arc required to drive home in
order to respond to an emergency involving any utility which is designed
specifically for and used to carry heavy tools, testing equipment or parts to
the extent that said truck could not be used for personal purposes other than
de minimus use.
   “Public Safety Officer” is an individual serving a public agency in an
official capacity, with or without compensation, as a law enforcement officer,
or a firefighter, chaplain, or member of a rescue squad or ambulance crew.
   A “taxable vehicle” is a vehicle other than a public safety and special use
vehicle or a nonpersonal use vehicle.
   “Taxable fringe benefits” means that portion of an employee's or official's
use of a city-owned vehicle that is for personal, nonbusiness purposes.
   “Unmarked qualified non-personal use law enforcement vehicles” are:
   a.   Owned by the City of Columbus;
   b.   Authorized tor personal use by a Public Safety Officer, but such use
must be incident to use for law-enforcement purposes. The greatest law-
enforcement purpose is Public Safety Officers having a law enforcement vehicle
available in order to immediately respond to emergency situations involving his
or her job duties; and
   c.   Operated by a certified full-time Public Safety Officer who is
responsible for prevention or investigation of crime, is authorized to carry
firearms, execute warrants and make arrests, and is required to carry a firearm
while operating the vehicle, except when it is not possible to do so because of
the requirements of undercover work.
   B.   Prohibition on Personal Use. No employee or official of the city shall
use any city-owned vehicle for any personal, nonbusiness purposes (other than
de minimum use such as a stop for a meal between business functions), unless
specifically authorized by the control employee he reports to and such use is
incidental to his city government functions.
   C.   City employees permitted to take vehicles to their residence.
   1.   Employees who are not public safety officers. control employees may
specifically authorize or require an city employee to take a city-owned vehicle
to his or her residence when the employee is not working if it is determined
that the employee must have such vehicle available in order to immediately
respond from his or her residence to emergency situations involving his or her
job duties. In such cases, once the vehicle is taken to the employee's
residence, the employee may not use the vehicle for personal purposes. It is
the intent of the common council that any use of a city-owned vehicle
authorized under this section shall be considered a bona fide business
requirement of the city and, therefore, any value to the employee attributed to
such use shall be excludable from the employee's income as a "working condition
fringe benefit" under the provisions of Section 132(d) of the Internal Revenue
Code, as now or hereafter amended. Control employees are to file a statement
with the city controller by January 31 of each year setting forth which city-
owned vehicle and employees will be permitted to take city-owned vehicles to
their residence and the reasons and rational therefor.
   2.   Employees who are Public Safety Officers. The Chief of Police may
specifically authorize or require a Public Safety Officer to take a marked
qualified non-personal use law enforcement vehicle or an unmarked qualified
non-personal use law enforcement vehicle to his or her residence when the
employee is not working if it is determined that the employee must have such
vehicle available in order to immediately respond from his or her residence to
emergency situations involving his or her job duties.
   a.   Public Safety Officers authorized or required to take a marked
qualified non-personal use law enforcement vehicle or an unmarked qualified
non-personal use law enforcement vehicle to his or her residence when the
employee is not working may operate the vehicle for personal use incident to
use for law-enforcement purposes, specifically for the law-enforcement purpose
to provide a Public Safety Officer who is always on call to have a law
enforcement vehicle available in order to immediately respond to emergency
situations involving his or her job duties, in Bartholomew County, counties
contiguous to Bartholomew County and other areas outside of these authorized
areas as approved by the Chief of Police or Deputy Chief. The Chief of Police
may restrict or suspend off-duty use as deemed necessary.
   b.   The Board of Public Works and Safety or the Chief of Police may add
additional restrictions on a Public Safety Officer's authorized or required use
of a marked qualified non-personal use law enforcement vehicle or an unmarked
qualified non-personal use law enforcement vehicle.
   c.   It is the intent of the common council that any use of a marked
qualified non-personal use law enforcement vehicle or an unmarked qualified
non-personal use law enforcement vehicle authorized under this section shall be
considered a bona fide business requirement of the city and. therefore, any
value to the employee attributed to such use shall be excludable from the
employee's income as a “working condition fringe benefit” under the provisions
of Section 132(d) of the Internal Revenue Code, as now or hereafter amended.
   D.   Inclusion in Gross Income. The value of any taxable vehicle or any
taxable fringe benefit as defined herein shall be included in the gross income
of the city official or employee.
   E.   Computation of taxes. Computation of taxes and withholding on the
additional gross income hereunder shall be determined by the city controller
based on the election of the employee operating the vehicle of either annual
lease value method, the cents-per-mile method or the three dollars per day
commuting rule. However, all control employees must use the annual lease value
method or the cents-per-day method. The city controller shall adhere to the
regulations promulgated by the department of treasury for computing the taxes
and withholding hereunder. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Ord. 19-2018, 2018; Prior code
§ 21-4)
2.80.050 Deferred compensation plan.
   A.   At the city council meeting in a regularly scheduled session, on the
second day of May, 1989, the city deferred compensation plan was established
for the voluntary participation of all eligible employees and elected
officials.
   B.   The city will utilize the state's plan document and its investment
options. The city will contract with Indiana Deferred Compensation Plan, Inc.
to be the exclusive servicing manager and enroller.
   C.   The common council appoints the controller as the administrator of the
plan and directs the board of public works and safety and/or the controller to
execute any and all documents necessary to implement said plan. The common
council also authorizes the controller to make deductions from the pay of
employees, who voluntarily participate, and to make such other arrangements as
are necessary to implement the plan. It is understood that, other than the
incidental expense of collecting the employees' deferrals and other minor
administrative matters, there is to be no cost to the city or contribution by
the city to this plan. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 21-6)
2.80.060 Coverage elected.
   The common council elects coverage under the old-age and survivors'
insurance as they may be implemented by regulations of the state agency.
(Amended during 1994 codification; prior code § 21-15)
2.80.070 Positions to be covered.
   All city positions are designated as those which are to be covered by the
old-age and survivors' insurance except the following:
   A.   All services of an emergency nature;
   B.   Part-time positions;
   C.   Positions which are compensated on a fee basis;
   D.   Elected legislative officials;
   E.   Elected judicial officials. (Prior code § 21-16)
Chapter 2.84
TELECOMMUNICATIONS FUND AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS REVIEW COMMITTEE
   
2.84.010   The fund.
   
2.84.020   Telecommunications review committee.
   
2.84.030   Duties and responsibilities.
   
2.84.040   Determination of city and county pro-rata share of franchise fee and
contribution to telecommunications commission budget.
   
2.84.050   Amendment or repeal of chapter.
   
2.84.060   Termination of chapter.
2.84.010 The fund.
   A.   The Bartholomew County telecommunications non-reverting fund,
hereinafter referred to as the fund, is established and Bartholomew County's
pro-rata share of the present Bartholomew Columbus telecommunications non-
reverting fund is transferred to this nonreverting fund. Bartholomew County's
pro-rata share of the present Bartholomew Columbus telecommunications
nonreverting fund shall equal that portion of the fund which the county manages
based on the fees paid by subscribers located outside the corporate boundaries
of the city of Columbus, Indiana. The Columbus telecommunications nonreverting
fund heretofore established under Ordinance No. 98-27, shall be deemed to be
the city's fund which is referenced within this chapter.
   B.   The Columbus city-clerk treasurer shall be responsible for paying all
expenses of the Bartholomew Columbus telecommunications commission budget
during the course of the calendar year. On or before July 15th of each year and
January 15th of each year, the Columbus city-clerk treasurer shall submit to
the Bartholomew County commissioners an itemized statement detailing the total
amount of the semi-annual expenses of the Bartholomew Columbus
telecommunication commission as of the immediately preceding June 30th and
December 31st of each year. Bartholomew County shall then promptly reimburse
the city as set forth below for the county's pro-rata share of the annual
operating budget of the Bartholomew Columbus telecommunications commission.
Further, the Columbus City clerk treasurer shall receive, invest and reinvest
the city's pro-rata share of any cable television franchise fees received under
any franchise agreement.
   C.   The county treasurer shall receive, invest and reinvest Bartholomew
County's pro-rata share of any cable television franchise fees received under
any franchise agreement. (Ord. 99-8 § 1, 1999)
2.84.020 Telecommunications review committee.
   A.   A committee is established to be known as the Bartholomew Columbus
telecommunications review committee which shall be comprised of the following:
   1.   Three members representing the city who shall be appointed as follows:
   a.   One member shall be appointed by the mayor.
   b.   One member shall be appointed by the president pro-tem of the city
council; and
   c.   One member, who is an employee of the department of community
development, shall be appointed by the director of the department of community
development.
   2.   Three members representing Bartholomew County who shall be appointed by
the county commissioners.
   B.   Appointments to the telecommunications review committee shall be made
as follows:
   1.   Initial appointments to the telecommunications review committee shall
be made by the city within thirty days of the date that the ordinance codified
in this chapter is passed by the city council and becomes effective.* Such
initial appointments shall be for the following periods:
   a.   The mayor's appointment shall expire December 31, 2000.
   b.   The president pro-tem of the city council's appointment shall expire
December 31, 2001.
   c.   The director of the department of community development's appointment
shall expire December 31, 2002.
   2.   Initial appointments to the telecommunications review committee shall
be made by Bartholomew County within thirty days of the passage of the
ordinance codified in this chapter by the Bartholomew County commissioners.
   3.   Subsequent appointments by the city to the telecommunications review
committee shall be for terms of three years and shall be made at the first
regular meeting of the Columbus city council in each year.
   4.   Subsequent appointments of Bartholomew County to the telecommunications
review committee shall be for terms of three years and shall be made, when
applicable, at the first regular meeting of the Bartholomew County
commissioners each year.
   5.   In the event that a successor has not been named to replace a member
upon the expiration of such member's term, such member shall continue to serve
until a successor has been duly appointed and qualified.
   6.   A majority of the telecommunications review committee shall mean four
members. (Ord. 99-8 § 2, 1999)
*     Editor's Note: Ordinance 99-8, which enacted Ch. 2.84, is effective on
April 20, 1999.
2.84.030 Duties and responsibilities.
   A.   The telecommunications review committee shall have the following duties
and responsibilities:
   1.   To prepare and establish guidelines governing the submission of
applications for funding requests from the telecommunications nonreverting fund
and to develop a set of standards and rules concerning purposes for which funds
may be expended. Such guidelines shall be submitted to the city council and the
county commissioners for final approval;
   2.   From time to time, as requested by the director of the department of
community development, the telecommunications commission, or the county
commissioners, to review applications for funding and make funding
recommendations to the appropriate governmental bodies as more particularly set
forth below;
   3.   To make an annual report to the common council of the city, the
Bartholomew County commissioners and the Bartholomew County council on
activities of the telecommunications review committee and the status of the
respective city and Bartholomew county nonreverting funds;
   4.   To promptly consider and make a recommendation either in favor of or in
opposition to applications for funding requests.
   a.   With respect to the city, the following shall apply:
   i.   From time to time, the telecommunications review committee may take
official action by granting or denying application packages and funding
recommendations that have been submitted. Those portions of such applications
and funding recommendations that pertain to the city's fund, if approved, shall
be certified, within thirty days, to the common council for final approval. If
an application or funding recommendation has been denied then that portion
which pertains to the city's fund shall be certified, within thirty days, to
the common council only upon the written request of the applicant. In the event
that such application does not receive a majority vote, the application shall
automatically be certified within thirty days to the common council. The
telecommunications review committee shall determine what portion of the
application applies to the city and what portion applies to the county. In the
event that an application is finally approved by only the city council, then
the funds for the cost of such application shall be paid for solely out of the
revenue from that governmental entity's share of the fund.
   ii.   Annually, the members of the telecommunications review committee shall
be obligated to develop a set of standards and applicable rules concerning the
processing of grants and the purposes and goals for which the grant money will
be utilized. Such standards shall include a limitation of the total annual
amounts being limited to a maximum of the annual interest earned on the
principal of the fund. However, this limitation shall not restrict the common
council from approving grants in excess of the interest earned. All approved
grants shall be required to receive a majority vote of the members of the
telecommunications review committee.
   b.   With respect to the county, the following shall apply:
   i.   From time to time, take official action by granting or denying
applications for funding requests that have been submitted to the
telecommunications review committee;
   ii.   Applications which are approved or which do not receive a majority
vote by the telecommunications review committee shall be certified within
thirty days, to the county commissioners for final approval. Applications which
are denied by the telecommunications review committee shall be certified to the
county commissioners only upon the written request of the applicant. In the
event that the county commissioners approve the request, it shall be forwarded
to the county council for the appropriation of funds from the county's
nonreverting fund, to pay the county's portion of such request. If the county
commissioners deny the request it will not be forwarded to the county council;
   iii.   In the event that an application would be approved by the county, but
denied by the city, the application shall be returned to the county
commissioners for a hearing to determine whether the county is willing to fund
the entire cost of the application solely from the county's portion of the
funds. If the county commissioners approve utilizing only county funds to fund
the application, the county council shall appropriate the necessary funds from
the county's nonreverting fund. If the county commissioners deny the
application it shall be deemed denied and shall not be forwarded to the county
council.
   B.   The department of community development shall provide staff support to
the telecommunications review committee, the board of public works and safety
and common council regarding activities of the telecommunications review
committee and the status of the city's and county's nonreverting funds.
   C.   The common council of the city shall have the following duties and
responsibilities as it relates to the telecommunications review committee and
to those funds in the city's nonreverting fund:
   1.   To take final action by resolution affirming, modifying or denying the
recommendations of the telecommunications review committee. Any resolution by
the city council is deemed to be final action on such application as it
pertains to those funds in the city's nonreverting fund;
   2.   To review the annual Bartholomew-Columbus telecommunications
commission's budget. The annual commission budget shall be submitted to the
county council for review and approval even though no tax money will be used to
support the telecommunication commission's operations;
   3.   To provide, for the use and benefit of the telecommunications
commission, an amount not to exceed one-half of the city's pro-rata share of
the annual franchise fee paid by the franchisee (cable operator) to fund the
operating budget (administrative expenses, e.g., travel, supplies, salary,
educational materials, etc.) of the telecommunications commission to enable the
commission to carry out its duties under the ordinance creating the commission
and the cable television franchise agreement.
   D.   The county commissioners shall have the following duties and
responsibilities as it relates to the telecommunications review committee and
to those funds in the county's nonreverting fund:
   1.   To take final action by resolution affirming, modifying or denying the
recommendations of the telecommunications review committee. Any resolution by
the county commissioners is deemed to be final action on such application.
   2.   To review the annual Bartholomew-Columbus telecommunications
commission's budget. The annual commission budget shall be submitted to the
county commissioners and county council for review and approval even though no
tax money will be used to support the telecommunication commission's
operations.
   3.   To provide, for the use and benefit of the telecommunications
commission, an amount not to exceed one-half of the county's pro-rata share of
the annual franchise fee paid by the franchisee (cable operator) to fund the
operating budget (administrative expenses, e.g., travel, supplies, salary,
educational materials, etc.) of the telecommunications commission to enable the
commission to carry out its duties under the ordinance creating the commission
and the cable television franchise agreement.
    E.   The county council shall have the following duties and
responsibilities as it relates to those funds in the county's nonreverting
fund:
   1.   To direct the disbursement of moneys constituting the fund held by the
treasurer;
   2.   To make funds available to the telecommunications commission or others
in the community as it deems fit and proper. (Ord. 99-8 § 3, 1999)
2.84.040 Determination of city and county pro-rata share of franchise fee and
contribution to telecommunications commission budget.
   A.   The city and the county shall bear the expense for the Bartholomew-
Columbus telecommunications commission budget on a pro-rata basis which shall
be determined as a percentage of the overall franchise fee paid by the
franchisee (cable operator) under the terms of the franchise agreement,
computed as follows:
   1.   The amount of fees generated from cable subscribers located within the
city limits of the city, divided by the total franchise fee, shall represent
the city's pro-rata share.
   2.   The amount of the fees generated from cable subscribers located outside
the city limits of the city, divided by the total franchise fee, shall
represent the county's pro-rata share. (For purposes of this chapter, fees
generated from subscribers located in other incorporated or unincorporated
towns within Bartholomew County, but covered by the franchise agreement, shall
be included within the county fees.)
   B.   The pro-rata share of expenses to be borne by the city and the county
each year shall be based upon the fees paid by city and county cable
subscribers in the previous calendar year. (Ord. 99-8 § 4, 1999)
2.84.050 Amendment or repeal of chapter.
   Given the reciprocal nature of this chapter and the shared responsibilities
between the city and Bartholomew County, this chapter may not be amended or
repealed by either the city or the county without the party seeking to amend or
repeal the chapter providing the other party with sixty days' prior written
notice of any proposed amendment or repeal. In the event that either the city
or the county, or both, would amend or repeal this chapter, in whole or in
part, any funds previously appropriated for existing projects or operations
will be paid through the end of the then existing budget year according to the
city's and county's then applicable pro-rata share. (Ord. 99-8 § 5, 1999)
2.84.060 Termination of chapter.
   In the event that the city or county shall abolish this chapter concerning
the telecommunications review committee, the county's share of the fund shall
immediately revert to the county's telecommunications review committee non-
reverting fund and such fund is created upon abolishing this chapter. (Ord. 99-
8 § 6, 1999)
Chapter 2.88
Columbus Department of Redevelopment and Redevelopment Commission
   
2.88.010   Establishment.
   
2.88.020   Funds.
2.88.010   Establishment.
   Pursuant to IC 36-7-14-3, the council establishes the city of Columbus
department of redevelopment (the “department”), for the purposes and to
exercise the powers set forth in the act or otherwise granted by law. The
department will be controlled by a board of five members to be known as the
city of Columbus redevelopment commission (the “redevelopment commission”), two
of whom shall be appointed by the council and three of whom shall be appointed
by the mayor of the city. (Ord. 03-25 § 1, 2003)
2.88.020   Funds.
   Any appropriation or expenditure of funds in excess of five hundred thousand
dollars by the commission shall be subject to approval by the council. (Ord.
03-25 § 2, 2003)
Chapter 2.92
Technology Advisory Committee
Sections:
   
2.92.010   Purpose.
   
2.92.020   Membership.
   
2.92.030   Appointments.
   
2.92.040   Current Technical Advisory Committee Fund and any future revenue or
income.
2.92.010 Purpose.
   It shall be the purpose of the technical advisory committee to serve as a
technical advisory resource to the city and the appropriate boards and
authorities. The technical advisory committee shall provide input and expertise
to the city and make recommendations to the city regarding its technical needs,
issues and planning on an as needed basis as matters may be brought before
them. Such matters may include, but not be limited to: review of technical
specifications of hardware and software purchases, recommendations of
technology types and vendors to be considered for RFP processes, external
oversight of expansion of the city's fiber optic communication network(s),
policy and procedure handling for broadband enablement for business and
residents of the city of Columbus.
(Ord. 49-2014 (part), 2014; Ord. 11-12 (part), 2011; Ord. 06-12 (part), 2006)
2.92.020 Membership.
   A.   Membership. The committee shall consist of seven members, each of whom
shall be appointed to a term not to exceed four years in duration.
   B.   Initial terms. The initial terms for the members will be as specified
hereafter. The second and subsequent terms will be for four years.
   C.   Expiration of terms. In the event a term expires, a committee member
will continue to serve until his or her successor is appointed.
   D.   Compensation. The members of the commission shall serve without
compensation. Such members may, however, be reimbursed for approved out-of-
pocket expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.
   E.   Quorum/majority vote. Four members of the committee will constitute a
quorum for the purpose of conducting the business of the committee. Decisions
of the committee must be approved by a majority of the members present.
   F.   Organization.
      1.   The committee shall conduct an organizational meeting no later than
January 31 of each calendar year for the purpose of electing the committee
chairperson, vice-chairperson, and establishing such operating committees as
may be necessary.
      2.   The committee shall further have authority to establish such
subcommittees as may be needed, from time to time, to conduct the business of
the committee. Subcommittees shall be established by resolution of the
committee and duly voted upon.
   G.   Meetings. The committee will meet at least quarterly or upon call of
its chairperson or any four members of the committee.
(Ord. 49-2014 (part), 2014; Ord. 11-12 (part), 2011; Ord. 06-12 (part), 2006)
2.92.030 Appointments.
   A.   Membership. The technology advisory committee shall consist of seven
members.
   B.   Mayoral appointments. The mayor shall appoint four members to such
committee.
   C.   Common council appointments. The common council shall appoint three
members to such committee.
   D.   Staggered terms. Upon establishment of the technology advisory
committee, the seven members appointed by each governmental unit shall be
appointed for the following terms of office:
      1.   One for a term of one year;
      2.   One for a term of two years;
      3.   One for a term of three years;
      4.   One for a term of four years (applicable to the mayoral appointment
only).
   Provided, however, that in all events each such initial term shall expire on
the appropriate anniversary date established in subsection F. of this section
for the appointment of members to such committee. When an initial term of
office expires, each new appointment shall be for a term of four years.
   E.   Effective date for initial appointments. All initial appointments to
the technology advisory committee shall be made within thirty days after the
effective date of this section.
   F.   Effective date for subsequent appointments. All subsequent appointments
to the technology advisory committee shall be made at the first regular meeting
of the governmental entity making each such appointment on or following January
1 of each year.
   G.   Succeeding members. In the event that a vacancy on the committee shall
exist by reason of death, resignation or removal of a member by the appointing
entity for cause, the vacancy shall be filled by the responsible entity for
appointing the member for the balance of the vacating member's term.
(Ord. 49-2014 (part), 2014; Ord. 11-12 (part), 2011; Ord. 06-12 (part), 2006)
2.92.040 Current technical advisory committee fund and any future revenue or
income.
   The technical advisory committee fund shall be considered dormant as of
January 1, 2015 and any remaining funds shall be transferred into the general
fund of the city. Any future revenue or income that was previously designated
as a revenue or income of the technical advisory committee fund shall be
deposited into the general fund of the city.
(Ord. 49-2014 (part), 2014; Ord. 11-12 (part), 2011; Ord. 06-12 (part), 2006)

2.50.010. The department of public works may also be referred to in the City of
Columbus Municipal Code as city garage department and/or department of
sanitation and/or streets and/or traffic and/or motor vehicle highway. All of
these terms are used interchangeably but department of public works shall be
the formal title.
(Ord. 23-2015 (part), 2015; Ord. 14-2012, 2012)

   The department shall have a director responsible for the day to day
supervision and operation of the city services set forth in Section
2.94.010 and shall be the department head. The department of public works
director shall report to the mayor.
(Ord. 23-2015 (part), 2015; Ord. 14-2012, 2012)

right-of-way acquisitions, and permitting of such projects. The department
shall be controlled and operated by the board of public works and safety
pursuant to Columbus Municipal Code
2.50.010.
(Ord. 15-2012 § 1, 2012)

of IC 36-9-7 et seq. City engineer is also referred to in the city of Columbus
Municipal Code and the Indiana Code, as City Civil Engineer and City Traffic
Engineer. All of these terms are used interchangeably.
(Ord. 15-2012 § 1, 2012)
Chapter 2.98
SUBSTANCE ABUSE PUBLIC FUNDING BOARD AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE SERVICES ADVISORY AND
ACCOUNTABILITY COMMITTEE
Sections:
   
2.98.010   Name.
   
2.98.020   Membership.
   
2.98.030   Organization.
   
2.98.040   Duties and responsibilities.
2.98.010 Name.
   The Substance Abuse Public Funding Board and Substance Abuse Services
Advisory and Accountability Committee are hereby established. (Ord. 2018-4,
2018)
2.98.020 Membership.
   A.   The Board shall consist of five voting members.
   B.   The Mayor and the Common Council of the City of Columbus, Indiana,
shall each appoint one member to such Board; the Board of Commissioners of
Bartholomew County, Indiana and the County Council of Bartholomew County shall
each appoint one member to such Board; and the Board of Trustees of the
Columbus Regional Hospital shall appoint one member to such Board.
   C.   Upon establishment of the Board, the member appointed by the Mayor
shall initially serve for a term of one year, the member appointed by the
Common Council of the City of Columbus shall initially serve for a term of four
years; the member appointed by Board of Commissioners shall initially serve a
term of two years and member appointed by the County Council of Bartholomew
County shall initially serve for a term of three years. Provided, however, that
in all events each such initial term shall expire on the appropriate
anniversary date established in division G. below for the appointment of
members to such Board.
   D.   Upon establishment of the Board, the member appointed by the Board of
Trustees of Columbus Regional Hospital shall be appointed for a term of four
years. Provided, however, that in all events such initial term shall expire on
the appropriate anniversary date established in division G. below for the
appointment of members to such Board.
   E.   When an initial term of office expires each new appointment shall be
for a term of four years.
   F.   All initial appointments to the Board shall be made within thirty days
after the effective date of this chapter.
   G.   All subsequent appointments to the Board shall be made at the first
regular meeting of the governmental entity or the Board of Trustees making each
such, appointment on or after January 1 of each year.
    H.   In the event, that a successor has not been named to replace a member
upon the expiration of such member’s term, such member shall continue to serve
until a successor has been duly appointed and qualified. (Ord. 2018-4, 2018)
2.98.030 Organization.
   A.   The Board shall meet within thirty days following the appointment of
all its members for the purposes of organizing and electing a chairman from
among its members. Thereafter, the Board shall meet during the month of
January, of each year, for the purpose to elect a chairman for the succeeding
calendar year. The chairman shall serve until a successor shall have been
selected.
   B.   The Board shall adopt such rules and regulations and select such other
officers as may be necessary to properly conduct its business.
   C.   The Board shall meet at least once during each calendar quarter for the
purposes of conducting its business and carrying out its duties and
responsibilities.
   D.   The members of the Board shall serve without compensation. Such members
may, however, be reimbursed for approved out of pocket expenses incurred in the
performance of their duties. (Ord. 2018-4, 2018)
2.98.040 Duties and responsibilities.
   The Board shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
   A.   Facilitate and encourage cooperation between Bartholomew County and the
City of Columbus and Columbus Regional Hospital to facilitate the Bard’s goals.
   B.   Forward projects and programs requesting funding on to the Substance
Abuse Services Advisory and Accountability Committee (“Committee”) as needed.
The Committee will include the below content expert members who will make
recommendations to the Board on projects and programs to be funded, ensure
operational accountability of substance abuse projects and programs funded by
the Board, and provide metrics on projects and programs.
      1.   Circuit Court Judge or designee;
      2.   Prosecutor or designee;
      3.   Bartholomew Country Sheriff or designee;
      4.   City of Columbus Police Chief or designee;
      5.   City of Columbus Administration designee;
      6.   Columbus Regional Health designee;
      7.   Director of Court Services or designee;
      8.   Criminal defense attorney;
      9.   Up to two service providers;
      10.   Representative of the alliance of substance abuse progress in
Bartholomew County (ASAP) or its successor organization;
      11.   Two community members, one appointed by the Mayor of Columbus and
one appointed by the Bartholomew County Commissioners;
   C.   The Board shall appoint a criminal defense attorney, up to two service
providers and as ASAP representative to the Committee. All other specific
members are set forth above. The Board shall determine if any other members
need to be added to the Committee. The Committee members chosen by the Board
shall have a term of office of one year and shall be appointed annually by the
Board on their first organizational meeting of the year.
   D.   Make budgetary recommendations to the Mayor and Common Council as to
expenditures and costs to the City of Columbus for substance abuse projects and
programs.
   E.   Monitor compliance with approved programs and services and recommend
improvements and changes.
   F.   With the advice and consent of the Mayor and Common Council, may pan,
negotiate and administer cooperative agreements between the City of Columbus
and service organization.
   G.   Make an annual report to the Mayor and Common Council of its
activities.
   H.   Perform such other duties and assume such other responsibilities as the
Mayor and Common Council may appropriately assign to it. (Ord. 2018-4, 2018)

Chapter 3.04
FISCAL PROVISIONS GENERALLY
   
3.04.010   Investment of funds.
   
3.04.020   Use of interest derived from investments.
   
3.04.030   Electronic transfer of funds.
