Chapter 12.04
STREET NAMES AND BUILDING NUMBERS
   
12.04.010   City map incorporated by reference.
   
12.04.020   Points of reference.
   
12.04.030   Numbering of buildings.
   
12.04.040   Numbering of squares.
   
12.04.050   Street numbering maps.
   
12.04.060   Odd and even numbering systems.
   
12.04.070   Procedure for assigning numbers.
   
12.04.080   Display of building numbers.
   
12.04.090   Composition and design of numbers.
   
12.04.100   Rules and regulations.
   
12.04.110   Department of code enforcement to verify number.
   
12.04.120   Bringing suits for injunction.
   
12.04.130   Review by certiorari.
12.04.010 City map incorporated by reference.
   A.   A map of the city setting out and showing the changes in street and
avenue names and designations, and also showing block numbers both north,
south, east and west for the annexed area which is now on file in the office of
the city clerk is incorporated by reference thereto and made part of this
chapter.
   B.   The map is available for public inspection during regular business
hours. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 27-1)
12.04.020 Points of reference.
   The following points of reference constitute the base lines of the
geographical grid system: commencing on the north line of Water Street as the
basis for numbering all streets running north and south; commencing on the
meridian running north and south through a point three hundred twelve feet west
of the southwest corner of Lindsay Street and First Street as the basis for
numbering all streets running east and west. (Prior code § 27-5)
12.04.030 Numbering of buildings.
   All buildings shall be numbered according to the geographical grid system
established for the city in 1879 by Ordinance No. 230. Such system is founded
upon base lines from which number lines designated by hundreds are assigned to
generally parallel grid lines. (Prior code § 27-4)
12.04.040 Numbering of squares.
   The numbering of squares which will be bounded by grid lines, assigned one
hundred numbers, and coincide with streets insofar as practical, shall be as
follows: numbers  from one to one hundred inclusive are assigned to the square
between Water Street and First Street, and the square between such meridian
line and Lindsay Street. In the same manner one hundred numbers in consecutive
hundreds are assigned to each successive square according to the grid system.
East and West grid lines are numbered 0, 100, 200, etc., from such meridian
line east, and 0, 100, 200, etc., from such meridian line west. North and south
grid lines are numbered in the same manner from the north line of Water Street.
Streets not beginning at the base line, further out in the community, will be
numbered according to such hundred block square designated by the grid line
number. (Prior code § 27-6)
12.04.050 Street numbering maps.
   A basic master set of reproducible street numbering maps shall be maintained
by the board of public works and safety and shall be revised necessary to
maintain current status in the future. In conjunction with the master street
name index, such base maps shall comprise a scale of one inch equaling three
hundred feet and shall contain all grid lines and numbers in sequential units
of one hundred. (Prior code § 27-7)
12.04.060 Odd and even numbering systems.
   On each street, odd numbers shall be assigned on the south side and even
numbers on the north side of streets running east and west; odd numbers on the
east side and even numbers on the west side of streets running north and south.
Streets at a forty-five degree angle or less from the north-south longitudinal
line will be numbered as north and south streets. Streets more than forty-five
degrees from the north-south longitudinal line will be numbered as east and
west streets. (Prior code § 27-8)
12.04.070 Procedure for assigning numbers.
   A.   The rule for assigning individual numbers is based on lot frontage. A
number is reserved for each fifteen feet of space or frontage, or fractional
part thereof, whether improved or vacant, and always commences numbering odd or
even consecutively outward from the base lines.
   B.   When a lot or parcel is twenty-five feet, thirty-three feet or forty
feet wide, one to three numbers are reserved. When over thirty feet and up to
sixty feet, two to four numbers are reserved. When property fronts on north or
west aside of streets, even numbers are reserved from each one hundred,
beginning with two. When property fronts on the south or east side of streets,
odd numbers are reserved in the same manner, beginning with one. Numbers are
reserved in that hundred block until all lots between the two grid lines are
numbered, then the next hundred begins. (Prior code § 27-9)
12.04.080 Display of building numbers.
   All owners of buildings within the city are required to cause to be
permanently attached in some public and conspicuous place on the outside of
such building, about or over the front entrance of such building, a proper
number plainly indicating by appropriate figure the number of such building.
(Prior code § 27-10)
12.04.090 Composition and design of numbers.
   All numbers assigned in accordance with this chapter shall be of durable,
weather-proof material and of a size not less than one and one-fourth by two
inches. (Prior code § 27-11)
12.04.100 Rules and regulations.
   A.   Numbers will be assigned outward from the zero points in the grid
system to the city plan commission's jurisdictional boundaries, and into
adjacent portions of the county where agreeable.
   B.   House numbers will be assigned in relation to the house location on the
lot or parcel. For example, a three hundred foot lot or parcel would typically
be assigned twenty house numbers and identified by the exact number
representing the placement of the house on the lot or parcel. Street number
assignment shall be based on parcel street frontage.
   C.   Half numbers shall be placed upon the entrance posts or over stairways
on any business buildings or other buildings where occupancy is separate and
distinct from its ground floor.
   D.   All cities and towns within the county, and in adjacent counties if
mutually agreeable, shall be given an opportunity to participate in the
numbering and street naming so that a systematic, coordinated and integrated
system may be achieved throughout the area.
   E.   Streets which curve in several directions will be numbered for the
entire length of the street based upon the major tendency to a north-south or
an east-west direction. A street of variable direction shall carry a name, not
a number.
   F.   Streets which are broken in continuity will be numbered in the same
manner as if they ran continuously.
   G.   Street directions (N., E., S. and W.) shall be included where necessary
on maps and street signs, as a part of the street name.
   H.   Streets shall be identified by street signs to show direction and
displacement of house numbers from base lines.
   I.   On private drives, cul-de-sacs, courts, etc., that are privately
maintained and not dedicated into the public street system, the street name and
numbering system must comply with these principles. A street name and number
must be provided for each apartment house building before delivery service can
be provided.
   J.   When a building has more than one delivery point, a separate number
must be provided for each entrance. If the project includes town house
apartments having separate entrances onto a street or court, each entrance must
have an individual number. A single street number cannot be accepted for a
group of apartment buildings.
   K.   The addresses of streets which now show small gaps or variations in
numbering will not be changed unless the present numbering pattern in confusing
or inconsistent with the overall numbering objectives. (Prior code § 27-12)
12.04.110 Department of code enforcement to verify number.
   The department of code enforcement on being informed of the exact location,
existing or proposed, shall designate and verify to the owner or occupant of
any building now being erected, in the process of construction or hereafter
being erected the correct number of such building. Any decision may be appealed
to the board of public works and safety for review. (Prior code § 27-13)
12.04.120 Bringing suits for injunction.
   The board of public works and safety may institute a suit for injunction in
the circuit or superior court of the county to restrain any person who shall
take down, alter, deface, destroy or conceal any number assigned to or placed
upon any building, or who shall place or substitute or permit to be placed or
substituted an erroneous or improper number upon any building, or who shall
allow an erroneous or improper number upon any building, or who shall allow an
erroneous or improper number to be retained upon any building. Such board may
institute a suit for mandatory injunction directing a person to correct a
building number in violation of the sections of this chapter, or to make the
same comply with its terms. If such board is successful in its suit, the
respondent shall bear the costs of the action including reasonable attorney's
fees. (Prior code § 27-14)
12.04.130 Review by certiorari.
   A decision of the board of public works and safety may be reviewed by
certiorari procedure. A petition for certiorari shall specify the grounds upon
which the petition alleges the illegality of the board's action, and must be
filed in the circuit or superior court of the county within thirty days after
the date of such decision. (Prior code § 27-15)
Chapter 12.08
THOROUGHFARE PLAN
   
12.08.010   Purpose.
   
12.08.020   Elements of thoroughfare plan.
   
12.08.030   Copies to be filed for public inspection.
   
12.08.040   Designation of thoroughfares.
   
12.08.050   Right-of-way width of streets to conform to policies.
   
12.08.060   Location and alignment of streets.
   
12.08.070   Consideration by public agencies.
   
12.08.080   Issuance of building and improvement location permits.
   
12.08.090   Reserved.
   
12.08.100   Taxing property for thoroughfare fund.
   
12.08.110   Authority for procedure.
   
12.08.120   Method of procedure to be used in financing improvements.
   
12.08.130   Long-range development program.
   
12.08.140   Continuing authority of plan commission.
   
12.08.150   Amendments.
12.08.010 Purpose.
   The purpose of this chapter shall be to promote the orderly development of
the city and to improve the health, safety, convenience and welfare of its
residents. It is the intent of this plan to insure that the highway system
shall be carefully planned; new community centers shall grow only with adequate
highway facilities; the needs of industry, business and agriculture shall be
recognized in future growth; residential areas shall provide safe and healthy
surroundings for family life; the development of the city shall be commensurate
with and promotive of the efficient and economical use of public funds; and
definite policies shall be formulated for the laying out, development and
improvement of public streets and highways and service to platted and unplatted
land, and providing for the establishment of a thoroughfare fund.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-17)
12.08.020 Elements of thoroughfare plan.
   The official thoroughfare plan of the city shall consist of a map entitled
“Thoroughfare Plan”; containing text, tables, illustrations, maps, photographs,
and internet links; and the provisions of all other ordinances making up and
being a part of the comprehensive plan of the city as the same may pertain to
streets and thoroughfares of the city and its jurisdictional area.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; Ord. 96-51 § 1, 1996; prior code § 27-18)
12.08.030 Copies to be filed for public inspection.
   The official thoroughfare plan map and ordinance shall be kept on file in
the office of the clerk and shall be subject to public examination during the
regular office hours of the clerk. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Ord. 10-21 (part),
2010; prior code § 27-31)
12.08.040 Designation of thoroughfares.
   The thoroughfares within the city and jurisdictional area are classified as
to width and type in accordance with their function, context, and adjacent land
use as a part of the thoroughfare system, and are designated as interstate,
principal arterial, minor arterial, collector, and local streets. With the
exception of local streets, such thoroughfares are specifically noted on the
thoroughfare plan map. Minimum right-of-way widths set forth in Appendix B
shall be reserved and street improvements shall be made as required by the city
ordinance providing for the control of the subdivision of land.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-19)
12.08.050 Right-of-way width of streets to conform to policies.
   Whenever a street designated in the thoroughfare plan is to be platted as a
part of a subdivision of land, the right-of-way width shall conform to the
policies and specified designations and indications in the thoroughfare plan;
provided, that where a street borders a tract of land to be subdivided, the
city engineer shall make a recommendation to the plan commission as to the
alignment of the roadway. The recommendation shall be based upon accepted
roadway design principles, and sound engineering judgment. The alignment shall
not be split by a property line so as to create a half-street.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-20)
12.08.060 Location and alignment of streets.
   A.   Wherever the locations of streets are indicated in the thoroughfare
plan as following existing roadways or tying into existing intersections, they
shall conform to such locations; provided, that streets lying wholly within a
subdivision, and not designated as following an existing roadway, may be varied
in their alignment when such variance promotes the plan of a neighborhood in
accordance with good planning and engineering principles, and if such alignment
provides for the continuity of traffic movement.
   B.   Streets which follow irregular alignment or indicate revised alignments
or are not referenced to established roadways shall follow in a general manner
the alignment shown in the thoroughfare plan. Street alignments shall be
subject to detailed surveys which may be made by the city engineer, the city
plan commission or other public agencies or by the owners of land to be
subdivided. Such surveys shall be subject to the approval of the city plan
commission in the acceptance of subdivision plans affecting such streets.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-21)
12.08.070 Consideration by public agencies.
   After adoption of the thoroughfare plan and this chapter, the common
council, the board of public works and safety or other governing bodies within
the territorial jurisdiction of the city plan commission shall be guided by and
give consideration to the general policy and pattern of development set out in
the thoroughfare plan in the authorization, construction, alteration or
abandonment of public roadways, public places, public structures and public
utilities.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-22)
12.08.080 Issuance of building and improvement location permits.
   A.   Building permits and improvement location permits shall be issued only
if the proposed street and thoroughfare rights-of-way as set forth by this plan
will be protected from encroachment and, for planning and zoning purposes, the
proposed street and thoroughfare right-of-way lines will be considered as the
front lot line of lots and tracts bordering on such streets and thoroughfares.
   B.   In unplatted areas, building permits and improvement location permits
may be issued by appropriate administrative officials, upon the presentation of
a certification from the city plan commission to the effect that the proposed
street and thoroughfare rights-of-way as set forth by this plan have been
protected from encroachment.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-23)
12.08.090 Reserved.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-24)
12.08.100 Taxing property for thoroughfare fund.
   The common council may levy a tax annually which shall not exceed five cents
on each one hundred dollars of taxable property within the city for the purpose
of a thoroughfare fund, which when collected shall be kept separate from the
other funds of the city, and shall be a continuing fund to be drawn upon by the
city board of public works and safety for work done under or in furtherance of
or in carrying out a part of the official thoroughfare plan.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-25)
12.08.110 Authority for procedure.
   In the carrying out of any project under the official thoroughfare plan, the
board of public works and safety shall proceed, and shall have authority under
the provisions of Indiana Code, 36-9-6.1, and the method of procedure shall
comply with the provisions of applicable state law; except, that the provisions
for remonstrance of resident freeholders shall not apply.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-26)
12.08.120 Method of procedure to be used in financing improvements.
   A.   The board of public works and safety, in the carrying out of any
project under the official thoroughfare plan adopted by this chapter, shall
consider and determine what proportionate part of the cost of such project or
of any separate phase of improvement thereunder shall be paid by the city out
of the thoroughfare fund, including any increase of damages ordered by any
court, as benefit to such city at large, and, at such time, shall determine the
amount, if any, of the total cost of any such phase of improvement under such
project, including damages awarded by such court, which shall be assessed as
benefits upon the real estate within a special benefit district.
   B.   In the event the cost of acquisition and the benefits assessed against
the city, by reason of any such project, shall, at any time, be in excess of
the amount of money then standing to the credit of the thoroughfare fund of the
city, the city shall have the power and the common council is authorized by
ordinance to issue a bond in the sum sufficient to pay for such benefit or any
part thereof, as it may be deemed necessary, and such bond shall be issued and
sold in the same form and manner and with the same rate of interest and with
such maturities as are by law provided for the issuance and sale of bonds of
the city for the general purpose thereof, and the proceeds of the sale of such
bonds shall be deposited in and accredited to the thoroughfare fund, which
shall be used in the payment for such cost of acquisition, and the benefits
assessed against the city at large and any increased damages which may be
ordered paid by any court on appeal.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-27)
12.08.130 Long-range development program.
   The board of public works and safety will be guided by a long-range
development program of thoroughfare improvements, which shall be based on the
recommended plans of the plan commission, for the purpose of coordinating
efficient and economic use of thoroughfare funds.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-28)
12.08.140 Continuing authority of plan commission.
   Subsequent to the adoption of the official thoroughfare plan and the passage
of this chapter, the plan commission may do the following:
      A.   Determine lines for new, extended, widened or narrowed thoroughfares
in any portion of the city and the jurisdictional area thereof;
      B.   Certify to the common council the amended or additional plan under
the same procedures as established for the certification and approval of the
official thoroughfare plan.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-29)
12.08.150 Amendments.
   In addition to the provisions of Section
12.08.140, amendments may be initiated as follows:
   A.   The common council may direct the plan commission to prepare an
amendment, as desired, and submit it to public hearing within sixty days after
formal written request by the common council.
   B.   The owners of fifty percent or more of the area of property abutting
upon a street may also petition the plan commission requesting an amendment to
the official thoroughfare plan.
   C.   Administrative amendments may be made by the city engineer and the
planning director. Administrative amendments include updating internal or
external hyperlinks, updating base mapping as new mapping or aerial photos
become available, updating digital files as software and/or storage media
changes.
(Ord. 10-21 (part), 2010; prior code § 27-30)
Chapter 12.12
STREETSCAPE DISTRICT
   
12.12.010   Establishment of the streetscape district.
   
12.12.020   Maintenance.
12.12.010 Establishment of the streetscape district.
   There is established the streetscape district on Washington Street between
Second Street and Seventh Street to include the sidewalks and intersections but
excluding the sidewalks adjacent to the Courthouse, the Commons and between
Sixth and Seventh Streets on Washington Street. (Ord. 90-54 § 1 (3) (part),
1990: prior code § 27-55A)
12.12.020 Maintenance.
   A.   Notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter, the city shall
perpetually maintain the downtown streetscape district, including all
landscaping, pursuant to standards established by the city engineer's office
and approved by the board of public works and safety, except however, that any
daily maintenance of sidewalks such as removal of snow, ice, other debris or
natural obstructions, sweeping and weed removal, shall be performed by the
landowner of any real estate adjacent to said sidewalk or right-of-way within
the downtown streetscape district.
   B.   The minimum standards recommended by the office of the city engineer
and approved by the board of public works and safety may not be decreased by
said board of public works and safety without first providing written notice to
all adjacent property owners within the streetscape district, notifying said
property owners that the office of the city engineer proposes to change such
standards. Such notice to the landowners shall provide at least ten days prior
notice of any proposed changes to the minimum maintenance standards adopted by
the board of public works and safety. (Ord. 90-54 § 1 (3) (part), 1990: prior
code § 27-55.1)
  Chapter 12.16
STREET VACATIONS
   
12.16.010   Vacation of public ways procedure.
12.16.010 Vacation of public ways procedure.
   A.   Persons who desire to vacate all or part of a public way or public
place shall follow the procedure set forth in Indiana Code, 36-7-3-12.
   B.   The city clerk shall maintain all vacation ordinances in his or her
office and maintain and update a listing entitled Exhibit A on a regular and
consistent basis, each time a new vacation ordinance is passed. Said Exhibit A
shall contain a listing of all vacation ordinances passed by the city. Said
exhibit shall be available to the public for examination during regular
business hours.
   C.   The common council hereto establishes a policy requiring public ways to
be vacated in accordance with the Columbus Subdivision Control Ordinance before
an ordinance vacating said public way will be adopted by the common council.
(Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Prior code § 27-57)
  Chapter 12.20
STREET TREES AND SHRUBS
Sections:
   
12.20.010   Definitions.
   
12.20.020   Authority and regulation of public tree care.
   
12.20.030   Street Tree Committee.
   
12.20.040   City Arborist.
   
12.20.050   Standards for tree care.
   
12.20.060   Public tree care business contractor insurance.
   
12.20.070   Prohibition against harming public trees.
   
12.20.080   Repealer.
   
12.20.090   Severability.
12.20.010 Definitions.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   “Adjacent property owner” means a person that owns property immediately next
to something, such as a public street or right-of-way.
   “American National Standards Institute (ANSI)” means the professional
specifications and standards governing safe and appropriate horticultural and
tree care practices, as periodically updated or revised, including but not
limited to the following American National Standard for Tree Care Operations
chapters:
   1.   ANSI A300 Tree, Shrub, and other Woody Plant Management - Standard
Practices:
   a.   Management of Trees and Shrubs During Site Planning, Site Development,
and Construction, most current edition;
   b.   Planting and Transplanting, most current edition;
   c.   Pruning, most current edition;
   d.   Root Management, most current edition; and
   e.   Tree Risk Assessment - Tree Structure Assessment, most current edition.
   2.   ANSI Z133.1 - American National Standards for Arboricultural Operations
- Safety Requirements, most current edition.
   3.   ANSI Z60.1 - American Standard for Nursery Stock, most current edition.
   “Arborist” means a professional who possesses the technical competence
gained through experience and related training to provide for or supervise the
management of trees and other woody plants in residential, commercial, and
public landscapes.
   “Boundary tree” means a tree that straddles boundary lines of privately-
owned property and public property or public streets.
   “City” means the City of Columbus, Indiana, including, but not limited to,
the Common Council, boards, departments and agencies, the City Arborist, or the
Street Tree Committee.
   “Median tree” means a tree located within a strip or island of land that
separates opposing lanes of traffic.
   “Nuisance” means any tree, or limb or root thereof, that has an infectious
disease or insect; is dead or dying; obstructs the view of traffic signs or the
free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; is an undesirable tree species; or
threatens public health, safety, and welfare.
   “Person” means a person, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company, or organization of any kind.
   “Public property” means any property owned or controlled by the city.
   “Public street” means the entire area between the boundary lines of
dedicated right-of-way open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for
the purpose of vehicular and pedestrian traffic within the corporate limits of
the city.
   “Public tree” means a tree located within the boundary lines of land owned
or controlled by the city, including public street, medians, parks, and other
public properties.
   “Owner” means the person in whom is vested the ownership, dominion, or title
of property.
   “Right-of-way” means a strip of land reserved for, occupied, or intended to
be occupied by transportation facilities, public utilities or other special
public uses. Right-of-way may be held in the form of easement or fee.
   “Street tree” means a tree next to a public street on a right-of-way that is
owned or controlled by the city.
   “Top” means the non-standard practice of cutting back limbs to stubs within
a tree's crown to such a degree that normal canopy removed disfigures the tree.
   “Tree” means a woody perennial plant, typically having a single stem or
trunk growing to a considerable height and bearing lateral branches at some
distance from the ground.
   “Tree care” means the planting, pruning, removal, treating, spraying, and
any other tree maintenance or planning or horticultural work intended for the
enhancement or preservation of trees and tree canopy, and the removal or
prevention of biotic agents like pests and diseases with potential to cause
tree damage. Tree care may also include pruning of tree limbs for above ground
utility clearance and care of tree roots for soil excavation near neighboring
construction improvements.
   “Tree work manual” means the official arboricultural specifications manual
of tree care as adopted by the city which specifies the policies, programs and
recommended best management practices of urban forestry in the city, including
a plan to plant and maintain trees on public property and within public streets
and descriptions of planting recommendations for size, spacing, and tree
species that are desirable and undesirable. (Ord. 4-2022, 2022)
12.20.020 Authority and regulation of public tree care.
   A.   City authority and regulations. The city has the authority and
responsibility to conserve and care for public trees, make such governing
regulations and guidance, and protect public property as may be necessary to
ensure public safety, proper operation of city transportation and utilities, or
to beautify the city.
   1.   The Common Council and city boards, departments and agencies will
coordinate as necessary to provide services as required and ensure compliance
under this chapter as it relates to trees on public property.
   2.   The city may remove or prune any public tree or part thereof which is
unhealthy, unsafe, or a nuisance to the extent possible under the prevailing
economic situation. Exceptions to this rule would be pruning for the betterment
of tree health and pruning or removal for development and improvement of public
infrastructure.
   3.   The city may remove or prune, to the extent possible under the
prevailing economic situation, or with cause order to be removed or pruned, at
the adjacent property owner's expense, any boundary tree or part thereof which
is unhealthy or unsafe and threatening public property. If removal or pruning
is ordered, the financial assistance program noted in Section
12.20.020(C) is available.
   4.   The city may with cause order to be removed or pruned, at the adjacent
property owner's expense, any private property tree or part thereof which is
unsafe and threatening public property.
   5.   The city may undertake or coordinate the planting of public trees for
the betterment of the city to the extent possible under the prevailing economic
situation.
   6.   The city will notify adjacent street right-of-way property owners of
any tree care to be performed with regard to street, median or boundary trees.
   7.   If the city finds it necessary to take emergency action concerning a
street, median, or boundary tree in order to protect life or property, it may
take action without issuing notice. This action is limited to removing
immediate danger.
   8.   The city will, to the extent allowed by public safety and convenience
and economic considerations, design construction development projects with
regard to minimizing damage to and loss of trees.
   B.   Adjacent property owners’ responsibility. Any person owning, occupying,
or in control of an adjacent street right-of-way property may, at the person's
own expense and liability, plant street and median trees or provide tree care
for street and median trees abutting the property owned, occupied, or
controlled by the person.
   1.   Adjacent property owners are permitted to plant adjacent street and
median trees in accordance with guidelines and best management practices
contained in the tree work manual.
   2.   Adjacent property owners are permitted to prune street, boundary, and
median trees in accordance with guidelines and best management practices
contained in the tree work manual. Exception to this rule would be for public
infrastructure improvements.
   3.   Adjacent property owners are permitted to remove only nuisance street,
boundary, and median trees in accordance with guidelines and best management
practices contained in the tree work manual. Exception to this rule would be
for public infrastructure improvements.
   4.   Adjacent property owners, to the extent allowed by public safety and
convenience and economic considerations, should design construction development
projects with regard to minimizing damage to and loss of trees.
   5.   Adjacent property owners should notify the city of adjacent street
right-of-way property owner's intent of providing tree care to street, median
or boundary trees.
   a.   If tree care is not in accordance with the tree work manual guidelines
and best management practices, the city may with cause order adjustments to the
provided tree care, at the owner's expense.
   b.   The city has a direct interest in how tree care is conducted within the
street right-of-way so to avoid damage to public utilities or other public
infrastructure; therefore, when tree work is conducted at any expense of the
adjacent property owner, the adjacent property owner's tree care business
contractor is to obtain insurance outlined in Section
12.20.060.
   C.   Financial assistance program. The city will participate in a program to
facilitate the removal and pruning of street, median and boundary trees. Trees
eligible for the program should be deemed dying, dead or hazardous by an
International Society of Arboriculture (ISA) certified arborist. For
applications received and approved by the city, the property owner will pay the
contracted service tree care company fifty percent of the cost of the tree care
and the city will pay the contracted service tree care company fifty percent of
the cost. This program shall be offered to residential property owners until
the funding appropriated for this purpose has been expended. (Ord. 4-2022,
2022)
12.20.030 Street Tree Committee.
   The Common Council hereby creates a "Street Tree Committee," hereinafter
referred to as the "Committee."
   A.   Membership. The Committee will consist of seven members and will
consist of one city staff member from each of the Departments of Planning,
Public Works, Parks and Recreation, Community Development and Engineering, the
City Code Enforcement officer and one member of the Board of Public Works.
   B.   Meetings. The Committee will meet a minimum of four times each year and
shall be convened by a member of the Public Works Department. The Committee may
schedule additional meetings as needed.
   C.   Duties. The Committee has the power to:
   1.   Promote cooperation between Common Council, boards, departments, and
other agencies, recognizing that they have interest in tree care and
enhancement and sustainability of the public tree resource.
   2.   Support, by way of facilitation, promotion and coordination, the
creation and maintenance of public awareness and education programs or
materials related to trees.
   3.   Review legislation, policy and programs related to public tree care.
   4.   Review and update the tree work manual.
   5.   Assist with the annual application to renew the Tree City USA
designation.
   6.   Maintain a list of recommended tree species for planting and a list of
prohibited species.
   7.   Promote and facilitate public/private/nonprofit partnerships to achieve
action items formed in planning documents related to the conservation of the
urban forest. (Ord. 4-2022, 2022)
12.20.040 City Arborist.
   The city may utilize a "City Arborist," hereinafter referred to as the
"Arborist", to the extent possible under the prevailing economic situation. The
position may be a consultant or a city employee and is expected to generally
adhere to the responsibilities below:
   A.   Is accountable to the Street Tree Committee;
   B.   Is an ISA certified arborist and tree risk assessment qualified person
trained, educated or skilled in forestry, horticulture, arboriculture, or
landscape architecture;
   C.   Advise the Department of Public Works and Safety on street tree care;
   D.   Review public tree species, placement, and installation specifications
for construction drawings and perform follow up inspections for the city
Engineering Department;
   E.   Review public tree species, placement, and installation for subdivision
drawings and perform follow up inspections for the city Planning Department;
   F.   Advise the city Parks and Recreation Department on park tree care;
   G.   Acts within the municipal government to ensure the health of individual
trees and the general health of the urban forest;
   H.   Educates the general public and municipal employees about the proper
care and benefit value of individual trees and the urban forest;
   I.   Administers tree regulations and maintains a citywide tree inventory;
   J.   Advises on policies and strategies to protect the public trees of
Columbus; and
   K.   Assists the Street Tree Committee with its duties. (Ord. 4-2022, 2022)
12.20.050 Standards for tree care.
   A.   Purpose for standards. To ensure that public tree care is done in
accordance with city, ANSI, and national best management practices that support
community safety, civic pride and ensure the long-term health, benefits, and
sustainability of the city's urban forest.
   B.   Documented street tree standards. Within the tree work manual, the city
will establish standards for street tree care and will provide the necessary
standards to all contractors and/or property owners making improvements in the
right-of way and/or conducting tree care in the city.
   C.   Standards review and revision. The City Arborist will periodically
review the tree work manual and provide any recommended changes to standards to
the Street Tree Committee for approval by the city Board of Public Works and
Safety.
   D.   Street, boundary and median trees. In accordance with the tree work
manual, the city will keep street, boundary, and median trees maintained so
that the tree does not obstruct the visibility and free use of public ways and
nuisance trees or parts thereof will be pruned or removed. If a street boundary
or median tree obstructs visibility or is a nuisance tree, identified by a
citizen, the financial assistance program noted in Section
12.20.020 is available.
   E.   Park trees. In accordance with the tree work manual, the city will keep
park trees maintained to mitigate potential public safety risk. Nuisance trees
or parts thereof shall be pruned or removed.
   F.   Interference. No person will hinder, prevent, delay, or interfere with
the city or their agents while engaged in carrying out the execution or
enforcement under this chapter. (Ord. 4-2022, 2022)
12.20.060 Public tree care business contractor insurance.
   A.   Any contractor providing public tree care will procure and maintain
during the life of contract, including the guarantee period and during any
warranty work, such insurance policies, including those set forth herein below,
as will protect itself from all claims for bodily injuries, death or property
damage which may arise under contract; whether the acts were made by the
contractor or by any subcontractor or anyone employed by them directly or
indirectly.
   B.   Where liability insurance policies are required to be filed, they will
be in accordance with the current standards and practices established by the
Department of Finance, Operations, and Risk.
   C.   The insurance policy will name the City of Columbus as an insured party
and provide evidence of the insurance, consisting of a certification executed
by an authorized agent of the insurance company indicating the amount and type
of insurance, the location of coverage and certifying that the insurance will
not be cancelled unless notice of intent to cancel is filed with the adjacent
property owner and the city department or agency unit at least ten days prior
to said cancellation. (Ord. 4-2022, 2022)
12.20.070 Prohibition against harming public trees.
   No person may cause harm to be done to public trees by any of the following
acts:
   A.   Top, break, injure, mutilate, deface, kill or destroy, or permit any
fire to burn where it will injure any tree;
   B.   Permit any toxic chemical, gas, smoke, brine, oil, or other injurious
substance to seep, drain, or to be emptied upon or about any tree; or
   C.   Excavate any ditch or trench in such a manner as to adversely affect
the health of a tree or damage the root system, with the exception of repairing
existing underground utilities and when no other viable options exist. (Ord. 4-
2022, 2022)
12.20.080 Repealer.
   Any ordinance part thereof heretofore adopted which in any manner conflicts
with any provisions of this chapter is hereby repealed to the extent of such
conflict. (Ord. 4-2022, 2022)
12.20.090 Severability.
   A.   Should any part or provision of this chapter be declared invalid by a
court of competent jurisdiction, the same will not affect the validity of the
chapter as a whole, or any part thereof, other than the part declared to be
invalid.
   B.   This chapter will be effective upon its passage by the City of
Columbus, Indiana Common Council and any publication required by law. (Ord. 4-
2022, 2022)
(ALP Supp. No. 15, 9-23)   182-2
 Chapter 12.24
STREET CUTS
   
12.24.010   Name. Scope.
   
12.24.020   Permit application.
   
12.24.030   Bond provisions.
   
12.24.040   Permit extensions.
   
12.24.050   Time of completion.
   
12.24.060   Excavation specifications.
   
12.24.070    Enforcement.
   
12.24.080   Penalties.
12.24.010 Name.
   This chapter shall be known as the "Columbus Street Cut Ordinance".
(Ord. 08-28, § 1, 2008; Ord. 96-55 § 1, 1996)
12.24.020 Scope.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cut, dig,
trench, excavate, grade, tunnel, bore or in any way disturb any road, street,
alley, sidewalk, curb, roadside ditch, right-of-way or other public place for
any purpose whatsoever, or to install any pole in any public street right of
way without first filing with the city engineer a written application for a
permit, and without first procuring such permit therefor, executing a bond to
cover all damages occasioned by such work, and restoring the place where such
work has been done in good condition, and in the manner provided by the terms
of this chapter; provided, however, that in case of an emergency, cutting and
excavation may proceed without delay on condition that within twenty-four hours
after the commencement of such cutting or excavation, a bond shall be posted,
notice of such work shall be given, and a permit shall be applied for and
obtained from the city engineer, all as required under this chapter; provided
further, however, that:
   1.   This chapter shall not apply to excavations made under contract with or
by order of the board of public works and safety of the city through its proper
officials, nor to construction of any private entrances, driveways or
approaches connecting with any street in the city street system or the
installation or replacement of sidewalks, or for the installation of
landscaping.
   2.   The provisions of this chapter pertaining to bonds and fees shall not
apply to work being done by any city, town, municipal corporation, or any other
county, or by any agency of the state, or by any special taxing or service
district established by law, provided that such entities shall give the city
engineer at least twenty-four hours' notice of any such work and shall comply
with all other applicable provisions of this chapter.
   3.   The provisions of this chapter pertaining to permits, bonds and fees
shall not apply to the setting and maintaining of utility poles and their
appurtenances along city street right-of-way by any public utility whose rates
are regulated by the Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission. (Ord. 08-28, § 1,
2008; Ord. 96-55 § 2, 1996)
12.24.030 Permit application.
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation desiring to cut, dig, trench, excavate,
grade, tunnel, bore or install any pole, or disturb any road, street, alley,
sidewalk, curb, roadside ditch, right-of-way or other public place, shall make
application for a permit therefor, which application shall he presented to the
city engineer for approval at least three days in advance of beginning the
work. Said application shall indicate the estimated time or dates during which
the cut, dig, trench, excavation, grade tunnel, bore or pole installation, is
to be made, shall describe the estimated kind and dimension in feet and inches
of the proposed work, together with the type of road surface, the nature of the
opening to be made and the exact purpose of the proposed work; said application
shall specifically describe the road, street, alley, sidewalk, curb, roadside
ditch, right-of-way or public place where such work is to be done. The city
engineer shall have the right to prescribe the method of the proposed cut, dig,
trench, excavation, grade, tunnel, bore, pole installation, and the location
and the time the proposed work shall be performed. Said applicant shall agree
in connection with each and every written application for each such permit to
do at least the following:
   1.   Maintain the road surface which has been disturbed in a smooth and
uniform condition for a period of one year after traffic is again permitted to
pass over such filled trench or maintain the area cut outside the pavement
surface but within the right-of-way, to a condition similar to the immediate
surrounding area for a period of one year. Such maintenance to meet the
approval of the city engineer.
   2.   Erect and maintain all necessary barricades, detour signs, warning
signals and lights by night (in conformance with the Indiana Manual of Uniform
Traffic Control Devices - latest edition) required to direct traffic safely
over or around the place where such work is being done, so long as the work in
any way interferes with traffic. At any location where traffic is limited to
one lane, a flagman shall be provided by the permittee.
   3.   Take all responsibility for any injury or damage resulting to persons
or property because of such work.
   4.   Conspicuously display at the site of such cut, dig, trench or
excavation opening the name and telephone number of the person to whom the
permit has been issued, so long as the cut, dig, trench or excavation is open
or barricades are in place.
   5.   Give notice to the city engineer prior to every day that excavations
are open. If the application is approved, a permit shall be issued by the city
engineer. Such permit shall state the period of time for which the same is
issued, shall be numbered and dated, and shall specifically describe the road,
street, alley, sidewalk, curb, roadside ditch, right-of-way or other public
place where such work is to be done and describe in detail the work to be done.
The city engineer shall keep on file all such applications and a record of all
permits granted. All permits issued in compliance with the terms of this
chapter shall be made in triplicate, the original of which shall be filed with
the city clerk, a copy shall he retained by the city engineer, and a copy given
the applicant for said permit. (Ord. 33-2023, 2023; Ord. 08-28, § 3, 2008; Ord.
96-55 § 3, 1996)
12.24.040 Bond provisions.
   A.   Whenever such application is approved, the applicant shall be required
to give a bond to the city, with surety to be approved by the city engineer,
which said bond shall guarantee that the place where said work is to be done
shall be restored to a condition (including any underground pipes, drains,
conduits, or wires) and in the manner provided by the provisions of this
chapter.
   B.   Such bond shall be in the sum of:
   1.   Two thousand dollars for each separate cut, dig, trench, excavation,
tunnel or bore, which crosses any road, street, alley, sidewalk, curb, roadside
ditch, right-of-way or other public place at an angle of not less than eighty
degrees nor more than one hundred degrees, or for each excavation within the
pavement not to exceed forty square feet in area;
   2.   Five thousand dollars per block or parts thereof, for each separate
cut, dig, trench, excavation, tunnel or bore which parallels or crosses any
road, street, alley, sidewalk, curb, roadside ditch, right-of-way or other
public place at less than eighty degrees nor more than one hundred degrees or
for each excavation within the pavement which exceeds forty square feet in
area.
   3.   Five hundred dollars for each pole installed in city right-of-way. For
the purpose of this section, a block shall be a five hundred foot long section
of street or a section of street between two intersections whichever is
shorter.
   C.   Such bond shall provide for the surety to guarantee that the principal
of said bond shall faithfully perform all the duties imposed upon said
principal for each and every cut, dig, trench, excavation, grade, tunnel or
bore, or for each and every pole installed in any city right-of-way according
to the requirements of this chapter. Such bond shall remain in full force for a
period of three years from the date of the completion of the permittee' s work
to assure that no hidden damage to drains or other underground structures
occurs. No permit shall he issued until such bond has been filed with and
approved by the city engineer. Anything contained herein to the contrary
notwithstanding, however, a cashier's check or certified check payable to the
city, in the same sum as designated herein for such bond, or a letter of credit
issued by a financial institution approved by the board of public works and
safety in said same sum as designated herein for such bond, may be filed with
such application in lieu of such surety bond; provided further, however, that
public utilities whose rates are regulated by the Indiana Utility Regulatory
Commission, and municipal utilities may submit an indemnifying agreement
acceptable to the board of public works and safety providing that the utility
shall comply with all the terms and conditions of this chapter, in lieu of such
bond, cashier's check, certified check or letter of credit.
(Ord. 08-28, § 4, 2008; Ord. 96-55 § 4, 1996)
12.24.050 Permit extensions.
   The holder of any permit issued which grants permission to cut, dig, trench,
grade, excavate, tunnel or bore, in or under any road, street, alley, sidewalk,
curb, roadside ditch, right-of-way or other public place, as provided by this
chapter, shall complete the work and repair the place or places where said work
is done within ninety days from the issuance of such permit. The city engineer
may extend the time for the completion of the work for which the permit was
granted. (Ord. 08-28, § 4, 2008; Ord. 96-55 § 5, 1996)
12.24.060 Time of completion.
   A.   The holder of any permit issued which grants permission to cut, dig,
trench, grade, excavate, tunnel or bore, in or under any road, street, alley,
sidewalk, curb, roadside ditch, right-of-way or other public place, as provided
in this chapter, shall complete all work including pavement repairs within
fourteen calendar days after beginning work at each location on any street
which is classified as a primary arterial, secondary arterial, one-way
arterial, or collector, and within sixty calendar days after beginning work on
all local streets and alleys. The permittee shall be responsible for making and
maintaining the temporary repairs to the satisfaction of the city engineer
until the permanent repairs are completed.
   B.   For any excavations made during the period from November 15 through
March 15 of each year, if weather conditions do not allow permanent repairs to
be completed, the permittee shall make temporary pavement repairs. Said
temporary repairs shall be made with asphalt cold mix and shall be maintained
by the permittee until permanent repairs can be made. Permanent repairs shall
be completed prior to the following April 15. All excavations made prior to
November 15 shall have permanent repairs completed by November 15 of the same
year. (Ord. 08-28, § 4, 2008; Ord. 96-55 § 6, 1996)
12.24.070 Excavation specifications.
   A.   All work and repair described herein shall be done in accordance with
standards and specifications prescribed by the city engineer. Before the
pavement is replaced said permittee shall call upon the city engineer to
inspect the work already done before proceeding further.
   B.   After said inspection has been made, said permit-tee shall complete the
work so that the place where excavated will conform to the road, street,
sidewalk or alley where such excavation was made as originally improved. All of
said work shall be done to the acceptance and satisfaction of the city
engineer.
   C.   In cases where any tile drain is cut, crushed or in any other way
disturbed so as to render the same in unsatisfactory working order, the
permittee shall cause such structure to be repaired or rerouted according to
the standards and specifications of the city engineer. Permittee shall
immediately notify the city engineer of any underground structures, drains,
pipes, conduits or wires struck during the work.
   D.   On any street which is classified as a primary arterial, secondary
arterial, or one-way arterial and on any street which has been paved or repaved
within the last five years, the permittee shall be required to use a method of
installation which will not require the disruption of the pavement unless the
permittee can demonstrate to the city engineer that such a method is impossible
or infeasible.
   E.   On any street which is classified as a primary arterial, secondary
arterial, one-way arterial, or collector, no work shall be done from 7:00 to 8:
30 A.M., from 3:30 to 5:30 P.M., or at any time on a Friday except in the case
of an emergency or if specifically allowed by the city engineer. (Ord. 08-28, §
4, 2008; Ord. 96-55 § 7, 1996)
12.24.080 Enforcement.
   A.   Whenever the board of public works and safety has reason to believe
that a violation of any provision of this chapter, or a rule or regulation
issued pursuant thereto, has occurred, it may cause a written notice to be
served upon the alleged violator or violators. The notice shall specify the
provisions of the chapter, rule or regulation alleged to be violated, and the
facts alleged to constitute a violation thereof, and may order that the
necessary corrective action be taken within a reasonable time. Any such order
shall become final unless, no later than five days after the date such order is
served, the person or persons warned may request in writing a hearing before
such board of public works and safety. In lieu of such order the board of
public works and safety may require that the alleged violator or violators
appear before it for a hearing at a time and place specified in the notice, to
answer the charges complained of, or the board of public works and safety may
initiate appropriate action for the recovery of penalty pursuant to Section
12.24.090 of this chapter.
   B.   After any hearing held pursuant to subsection A above, the board of
public works and safety shall affirm, modify or rescind its order or issue an
appropriate order or orders for the prevention, abatement or control of the
violation involved. Such order shall prescribe the date or dates by which the
violation or violations shall cease and may prescribe timetables for necessary
action in preventing or abating the violation or violations.
   C.   Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the board of public works and
safety from making efforts to obtain voluntary compliance through warning,
conference or any other appropriate means. (Ord. 08-28, § 4, 2008; Ord. 96-55 §
8, 1996)
12.24.090 Penalties.
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation which violates any provision of this
chapter, or any rule or regulation pursuant thereto shall be subject to a fine
not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars. Each day of violation shall
constitute a separate offense.
   B.   Action pursuant to subsection A above of this section shall not be a
bar to enforcement of this chapter, or any rules and regulations in force
pursuant thereto, and orders made pursuant to this chapter, by injunction or
other appropriate remedy. The board of public works and safety shall have the
power to institute and maintain the same in the name of the city any and all
such enforcement proceedings.
   C.   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abridge, limit or
otherwise impair the right of any persons or property, or to maintain any
action or other appropriate proceedings therefor. (Ord. 08-28, § 4, 2008; Ord.
96-55 § 10, 1996)
    Chapter 12.28
UTILITY POLES AND CABLES
   
12.28.010   Erecting or maintaining poles on Washington Street--Prohibited.
   
12.28.020   Carrying electric current.
   
12.28.030   Inspectors designated.
12.28.010 Erecting or maintaining poles on Washington Street--Prohibited.
   It is unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any wooden pole on
Washington Street in the city from Second Street to Eighth Street for the
purpose of supporting or carrying any wire in such street. Any steel, iron or
cement poles used for such purpose shall be not more than twenty-five feet
above ground. (Prior code § 23-2)
12.28.020 Carrying electric current.
   It is unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any pole on or along
Washington Street in the city from Second Street to Eighth Street for the
purpose of carrying electric current; provided, that this section shall not
apply to any pole set by the city at a street intersection on Washington Street
for the purpose of carrying current to light the intersection by street lights.
(Prior code § 23-3)
12.28.030 Inspectors designated.
   The chief of the fire department and the chief code enforcement officer are
designated and appointed inspectors to compel compliance with the requirements
of this chapter. (Prior code § 23-4)
  Chapter 12.32
PARKS AND RECREATION
   
12.32.010   Authority to operate.
   
12.32.020   Governing state law.
   
12.32.030   Establishment of playgrounds and recreational centers.
   
12.32.040   Recreation fund.
   
12.32.050   Hours.
   
12.32.060   Speed limit.
   
12.32.070   Motorized vehicle defined.
   
12.32.080   Exemptions.
   
12.32.090   Motor vehicles on People Trails prohibited.
   
12.32.100   Motor vehicles--Restricted to designated roadways--Exceptions.
   
12.32.110   Motor vehicles--Unsafe operation prohibited.
   
12.32.120   Parking restricted.
   
12.32.130   Musical groups--Prior approval required.
   
12.32.140   Use of golf courses restricted.
   
12.32.150   Defacement of property prohibited.
   
12.32.160   Sales of products and services--Prior approval required.
   
12.32.170   Bankcards honored for retail sales.
   
12.32.180   Snowmobiles prohibited.
   
12.32.190   Violations--Penalties.
12.32.010 Authority to operate.
   The city may establish, aid, maintain and operate public parks, playgrounds,
and recreation facilities and programs. (Prior code § 19-1)
12.32.020 Governing state law.
   The Park and Recreation Law found in Indiana Code, 36-10-3-1 et seq., shall
govern operation of the park and recreation department. (Prior code § 19-2)
12.32.030 Establishment of playgrounds and recreational centers.
   There shall be established, equipped and maintained by the city as many
playground and recreational centers in the city as shall be deemed necessary by
the board of parks and recreation of the city. Full control and custody of such
public playgrounds and recreational centers, including policing and
preservation of order thereon, is fully vested in such board of the city.
(Prior code § 19-3)
12.32.040 Recreation fund.
   The playgrounds and recreational centers of the city shall be provided for
by the park fund created by law. (Prior code § 19-4)
12.32.050 Hours.
   All playgrounds, parks and recreational centers of the city shall be open to
the public from sunrise to eleven p.m. unless otherwise posted; except, that
cemeteries shall be open to the public from seven a.m. until eight p.m. (Prior
code § 19-16)
12.32.060 Speed limit.
   A posted speed limit of fifteen miles per hour is imposed on all roads in
and around cemeteries, playgrounds, parks and recreational centers of the city.
(Prior code § 19-17)
12.32.070 Motorized vehicle defined.
   A.   For purposes of Sections 12.32.080 through 12.32.110, the term
"motorized vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, automobiles, trucks,
recreational vehicles, motorcycles, motorbikes, go-carts, off-road vehicles and
mopeds.
   B.   For purposes of said sections, the term "motorized vehicle" shall not
include golf carts; provided, that the same are operated in a safe and
responsible manner on golf course property and with the knowledge an consent of
the golf pro, assistant pro or other person duly authorized to give such
consent. (Ord. 90-4 §§ 5, 6, 1990: prior code § 19-17.5)
12.32.080 Exemptions.
   Sections 12.32.090 through 12.32.110 shall not apply to the orderly and
controlled parking of motorized vehicles at sporting or social events which are
officially sanctioned or recognized by the park and recreation department and
where said parking is made necessary by space or traffic-control
considerations. (Ord. 90-4 § 4, 1990: prior code § 19-17.4)
12.32.090 Motor vehicles on People Trails prohibited.
   It is unlawful for any person, except duly authorized law enforcement, fire,
paramedic and emergency medical personnel and park department and supervisory
and maintenance personnel acting within the scope of their official duties, to
operate a motorized vehicle upon the premises of the area known and referred to
as the People Trails of the city. (Ord. 90-4 § 1, 1990: prior code § 19-17.1)
12.32.100 Motor vehicles--Restricted to designated roadways--Exceptions.
   It is unlawful for any person, except duly authorized law enforcement, fire,
paramedic and emergency medical personnel and park department supervisory and
maintenance personnel acting within the scope of their official duties, to
operate a motorized vehicle upon the premises of land in all areas, other than
officially designated roadways, of parks, playgrounds, cemeteries, golf courses
and recreational areas of the city. (Ord. 90-4 § 2, 1990: prior code § 19-17.2)
12.32.110 Motor vehicles--Unsafe operation prohibited.
   It is unlawful for any person to operate a motorized vehicle upon the
premises of and in all areas of parks, playgrounds, cemeteries, golf courses
and recreational areas of the city in an unsafe manner or in such a manner as
to cause damage or injury to persons or property. (Ord. 90-4 § 3, 1990: prior
code § 19-17.3)
12.32.120 Parking restricted.
   Parking shall be prohibited in all areas of cemeteries, playgrounds, parks
and recreational centers of the city marked with "No Parking" and "No Parking
on the Grass" signs or a yellow curb. (Prior code § 19-18)
12.32.130 Musical groups--Prior approval required.
   Musical groups or other persons using amplifiers shall not be permitted in
cemeteries, playgrounds, parks and recreational centers of the city without
prior approval of the parks and recreation board. (Prior code § 19-19)
12.32.140 Use of golf courses restricted.
   No person shall be allowed on Greenbelt and Par-3 golf courses when open for
play without paying greens fees or without golf clubs. This prohibition
includes bicyclists, joggers, persons with pets and children who are not paying
golf customers. (Prior code § 19-20)
12.32.150 Defacement of property prohibited.
   It is unlawful to deface trees, shrubs, plants, turf or any park buildings,
facilities or property in the cemetery or park system of the city. (Prior code
§ 19-21)
12.32.160 Sales of products and services--Prior approval required.
   It is unlawful to provide any article, product, service or entertainment for
sale within a playground, park or recreational center of the city without the
prior consent of the parks and recreational board. (Prior code § 19-22)
12.32.170 Bankcards honored for retail sales.
   The park board shall be permitted to honor bankcards issued by Irwin Union
Bank & Trust and other financial institutions who are members of the MasterCard
International or VISA, USA, in connection with the retail sale of goods or
services at the Lincoln Center Pro Shop. (Prior code § 19-22.1)
12.32.180 Snowmobiles prohibited.
   Use of snowmobiles is prohibited in all cemeteries, playgrounds, parks and
recreational areas of the city. (Prior code § 19-23)
12.32.190 Violations--Penalties.
   Any violation of this chapter shall subject the offender, upon conviction,
to a fine of not less than one dollar nor more than three hundred dollars. In
addition, the department of parks and recreation shall have the right to
recover the cost of any actual damages resulting from such violation. (Prior
code § 19-24)
Chapter 12.36
DESIGNATION OF WORKSITE LOCATIONS
   
12.36.010   Establishment of site-Safety precautions.
12.36.010 Establishment of site-Safety precautions.
   A worksite may be established along any street or highway within the
jurisdictional boundaries for the purpose of construction or maintenance
activity by city employees; and
   A worksite may be established along any street or highway within the
jurisdictional boundaries for the purpose of private construction or
maintenance activity; and
   The authority to determine and establish a worksite as described above will
be the responsibility of the city engineer or the department head or manager of
the department performing the major portion of the work in the worksite;
provided, however, once the worksite is established, the city engineer will
establish the appropriate speed limit for the established worksite; and
   The establishing authority shall post signs notifying the traveling public
of the temporary maximum speed limits established under this section; and
   Signs shall be posted showing the designated worksite and the speed limits
at the worksite shall be reduced at least ten miles per hour below the maximum
established speed limit for that particular area and a worksite speed limit may
not exceed forty-five miles per hour in any location and not be reduced to less
than twenty miles per hour in any location; and
   A flagperson or persons may be used in addition to the traffic control
devices for the safety of worksite workers. A worksite shall be established if
a flagperson(s) is to be used for more than a short temporary duration of time
exceeding one-half hour continuous traffic control for any given work project.
Flagpersons shall follow established standards by IOSHA 1926.201; and
   Lighting for nighttime work, as required, will be supplied by the agency
doing the work; and
   This section does not apply to public safety employees during performance of
emergency duties; and
   In the case of private construction or maintenance, the city engineer may,
upon application from the persons performing the major portion of the work,
establish a worksite; and
   The required signs shall be posted and will be supplied by the private
contractor and they must meet approval of the city engineer's office; and
   Enforcement for the designated worksite speed limits shall be enforced
according to I.C. 9-21-8-41. (Ord. 95-35, 1995)
